Quiz "2" (you'll take Quiz "1" the week of Thanksgiving) will cover

  • Material from the "Intro to Gen Chem Lab"

data.assign_desc:
All health science students in all programs are required to meet the immunization requirements. Please review the requirements and follow the instructions listed.

All immunizations must be started immediately and no later June 1, 2016, and completed by the time you arrive for Welcome Week activities. The University immunization requirements can be viewed on the Creighton Center for Health and Counseling website (Health Science students heading, not New/Transfer). You are required to be compliant with the health science student requirements by the beginning of instruction.  Some immunizations require a series of shots so it is essential you plan accordingly.

A completion form (aka Health History Form or Bubble Sheet) has been sent to you via US Mail by the Admission Office in your acceptance letter. This should be returned to Student Health (as instructed). To verify that your information has been received by Student Health, log into NEST and click on "Immunization Tracker". This shows compliance or non-compliance based on the information submitted to Student Health. If all documentation is not submitted with the bubble sheet, you may follow up with Student Health directly through the following methods:

  • Fax Documentation: 402-280-1859
  • Scanned documents sent via email: studenthealth@creighton.edu
  • Mail to Student Health: 2500 California Plaza, Harper Center Suite 1034, Omaha, NE 68178

The official policy, which you are required to be familiar with and understand, for the School of Pharmacy and Health Professions related to experiential education and immunization requirements, can be HERE. 

Immunizations are available at Health Services at Creighton University; please call 402-280-2735 for an appointment.  If you are not in the Omaha area, you must work with your local provider to meet the requirements.  If you have questions, please contact Health Services.  For Regis OT pathway students only, Regis University is not able to accommodate requirements during the summer.  

You may also find these helpful tips of use when having to located your immunization records.

Once you have read this information and submitted your completed History Form, click "Take Quiz" at the bottom of this page.

data.assign_desc:
The Financial Aid Office is critical to your success at Creighton. The information below explains how financial aid is administered for the 2016-2017 academic year.

Welcome to Creighton University and the services offered by the Financial Aid Office. We coordinate the aid opportunities for all of Creighton’s four undergraduate and five graduate/professional schools/colleges, so there are very few students we do not touch. We help to administer $230 million dollars in student aid each year from federal, state, institutional and private sources.

Videos Tutorials

  • How to use NEST (Links to an external site.)
  • Finance your professional education (Links to an external site.)

Below, a short outline describes important information about financial aid specifically related to loan assistance and items to pay close attention to when accepting aid.

I. Financial Aid in NEST

  • Check for missing documents
  • Accept aid offer, complete the Master Promissory Note and Grad PLUS Loan Master Promissory Note and Entrance Counseling on the Direct Loan Web Site, www.studentloans.gov (Links to an external site.) 
  • Track loan debt while attending Creighton University
  • Update mailing address
  • View student account information
  • Create authorized user
  • Sign up for electronic refunds

II. Financial Aid Disbursements

  • August 17, 2016
  • January 4, 2017

III. Refund (if you are receiving funds in excess of tuition and fees)

  • Generally available within 2 business days of disbursement
  • Must sign up for direct deposit to receive the refund by providing bank account information in NEST

IV. Future Years

  • Aid will be disbursed at the beginning of each term
  • Must complete a FAFSA each year – any time after October for the following year

V. Student Loans

  • Types
    • Direct Unsubsidized Loan - Current interest rate of 5.31%, 1.068% origination fee withheld from each disbursement, 6 month grace period, interest accrues while in school.
    • Direct Grad PLUS – Current interest rate of 6.31%, 4.272% origination fee withheld from each disbursement, 6 month grace period, interest accrues while in school.

Feel free to contact us during business hours at 402-280-2731 or 800-282-5835. You can also email Dean Obenauer, Assistant Director of Financial Aid at deanobenauer@creighton.edu.  The Financial Aid (Links to an external site.) website is always available.

Once you have read this information, listened to the audio and viewed the video, click "Take Quiz" at the bottom of this page.

data.assign_desc:
There are 2 parts to this background check procedure.  SCROLL down for Part 2.

The Creighton University School of Pharmacy and Health Professions requires criminal background checks for all enrolled students in order to verify an individual's suitability to participate in experiential education rotations and to ensure patient safety. The Criminal Background Check process for all students has two parts:

PART 1:
Certiphi Criminal Background Check

Certiphi is the company that completes all criminal background checks for School of Pharmacy and Health Professions students. Please follow the instructions below for completing a criminal background check through Certiphi Screening, Inc.

1. Click the link or paste it into your browser: http://www.applicationstation.com

2. Enter the Code: CREIGHTONCBC-OT in the Application Station Code field.

3. Click the "SIGN UP NOW" button to create an account.

4. Follow the instructions on the Application Station web site.

If you have technical issues visiting the Application Station site, please contact Application Station Support at: 888-291-1369 x2006.

If you have questions or concerns regarding this request, please contact the SPAHP Office of Admission at 402-280-2662.

 

PART 2:
Nebraska DHHS Request for Information from the Adult and Child Abuse and Neglect Registry

The state of Nebraska requires by law that all incoming health science students complete this step before officially enrolling in a health science program. This is regardless of whether you currently reside, previously resided, or plan on residing in the state of Nebraska in the future. A form from the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services is available on this page. This form needs to be completed, must be NOTARIZED (despite what is indicated on the form), and sent back to the Office of Admission NO LATER THAN June 15, 2016. Below are a couple of important reminders/suggestions for completing the form:

  • Be sure to accurately TYPE all personal information into the form, and include as much detail as possible. Agency information (Agency ID Number, Agency Name) and information regarding they type of check has been provided for you.
  • Print the form
  • Do not sign the form until you are in the presence of a Notary Public.
  • Arrange to sign the form in the presence of a Notary Public and have the form notarized.
  • Please pay close attention to your signature; it must be legible. If it is illegible the agency will ignore the request.
  • Mail the form to:
    SPAHP Office of Admission
    Criss Health Science III, Room 151
    2500 California Plaza
    Omaha, NE 68178 

Once you have read this information and mailed your form, click "Take Quiz" at the bottom of this page.

data.assign_desc:
As you read the article for discussion in class, use the following questions to help guide your reading. Answer each question as part of your preparation. Copy and paste the following questions into your reply.

1. What research questions are the authors attempting to answer?

2. What theory are they using to guide their research? Identify the theory and briefly explain the main components of the theory.

3. Is this research quantitative or qualitative?

4. Describe the participants or research subjects for this article.

5. What instruments were used to collect data?

6. What was the form of the data collected?

7. What methods were employed to analyze the data?

8. What were the results of the analysis?

9. What conclusions did the authors draw based on this research?

10. What are the limitations of this research?

11. What practical utility do you see for this research?

  • Material from the Synthesis Experiment.
    • The quiz will include at least one of the following questions

      • It is common for synthetic experiments to give less than 100% yield, even when the experiment is performed exactly as specified and no crystals are lost in transfer.  Given what you know about solubilities, be able to explain why this is true.

      • Here are the melting and boiling points of some of the substances we use in this lab:

        • Potassium oxalate monohydrate: mp = 356 °C

        • Copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate: mp = 110°C

        • Potassium diaquadioxaltocuprate(II): decomposes above 200 °C

        •  Acetone: mp: -95°C, bp:56°C

        •  Ethanol: mp: -114.3 °C, bp: 78.4 °C

        •  Water: mp: 0°C, bp: 100°C

           Given these values, what range of oven temperatures would be acceptable for drying your sample?  Be able to justify your answer.  Hint:  think about where each of these substances ends up at the end - not all of them are on the watchglass!

  • Material from the Elemental Analysis Experiment

data.assign_desc:
Post-lab write-up

 II. Observations

   weight of nutmeg used; amounts of solvents used             

   weight of crude and recrystallized trimyristin                                

   melting point of recrystallized trimyristin  

   attach IR spectrum                                            

III. Conclusions

Show all calculations:

    % trimyristin in nutmeg based on recrystallized trimyristin

    % recovery of recrystallized trimyristin based on crude trimyristin

Assess purity of trimyristin isolated based on melting point (comment on m.pt. value as well  as range).            

Label the following absorptions ON the IR spectrum, and attach to the lab report: C-H bending and stretching frequencies, C=O stretching frequency, C-O stretching frequency.

IV. Summary Questions

 1. (3 points) A student from CHM 322 weighed 5.4 g of nutmeg, ground it to a powder, and heated it at reflux in methylene chloride to obtain crude trimyristin. The crude trimyristin was recrystallized with 95% ethanol, giving 3.5 x 10-3 mol of chemically pure trimyristin.

a) How many grams of trimyristin was isolated? Show your calculation.

b) What percent of the nutmeg sample was trimyristin? Show your calculation.

2. (3 points) See the generic reaction on p.78 of your lab manual for the saponification of a triglyceride. If you were to carry out the saponification of 1 mole of trimyristin, draw the structures of the products you would obtain. How many moles of each product would result?  (All you need to do is compare the generic structure provided on p. 78 to that of trimyristin to determine what R, R' and R" are, and draw the relevant products).

data.assign_desc:
For this assignment, You will develop a topic proposal and create an annotated bibliography.  You will use the sources that you find to write a 1500 word paper on an assigned subtopic of this year’s paper theme: Perception and Communication in the Natural World. 

 

1. Before you start this assignment, you will receive your assigned paper subtopic via a message through BlueLine. These subtopic are still very broad and you will need to narrow the focus of your paper within your assigned subtopic. Begin by searching for general information about your sub-topic and look for particular subjects or examples that you find interesting. 

2. Choose potential keywords for a database search; Enter those keywords into the database and continually refine your searches until you find articles that are pertinent to your subtopic or specific paper topic. Use the database tutorial which can be accessed via a link on the BIO 205 Course Guide on the Library website.

3. Read the abstract of articles that seem promising from their titles and keywords

4. Download the full text of articles that seem as though they may be helpful in writing a paper and skim them.  If an article seems particularly helpful, analyze it carefully using the paper analysis skills you practiced earlier in the semester.

5. Continually refine your topic and database search using information you learn from the abstracts and articles that you read.

6. Ultimately, select the articles, books, and reports that you anticipate using to write your paper.

7. Prepare a short statement (2-5 sentences) that briefly describes the narrow topic on which you plan to focus your paper. 

8. Create a bibliography using the formatting guidelines given above.  At this stage you must have at least 5 articles from the primary literature.

9. Annotate your bibliography. Each annotation must include:

  • The DOI of articles accessed electronically or an indication that the source was print only.
  • An indication if the source is from the scientific literature and if it is, whether it is primary or secondary.
  • A brief description written in complete sentences of what the paper is about, what information you plan to get from the source and how you plan to use it to prepare your paper. To successfully annotate your bibliography, you must have read and analyzed the papers you include and have thought critically about the structure of your paper. Each annotation should be between approximately 50 and 150 words.

9. Submit your bibliography ONLINE using the submit assignment button.

Note: For a scientist, searching for and reading the scientific literature is an ongoing task.  As you learn more about your topic and write your paper, you may find yourself searching for new articles.

You will be given 3 scenarios where you will be asked to compose an email response for each scenario. Utilize all communication skills that you have learned throughout the semester to create a professional and appropriate email response. Only one of the emails will be graded.

Instructions:

  • Compose an individual email for each scenario and send via Creighton Microsoft Outlook/Web Access to RyanDull@creighton.edu 
    • The subject line for the emails must begin with:
      • Scenario 1:

data.assign_desc:
As you complete the 100 level pre-pharmacy seminar, it is appropriate to gauge your progress towards a competitive application. The following information will be collected from you for the purpose of your own self-assessment and to assist with determining if you will move into the 200 level year-long seminar for pre-pharmacy students - PRx 200. Since the primary focus of PRx 200 is preparing the application, only students who are on track to apply should be enrolled in these classes, in most cases.  You will not be registering for these classes online. The EDGE staff will handle registration of students based on: a) their request to enroll in the seminar and, b) a review of their current academic preparation.  Students who are not considered eligible for enrollment in the 200 level seminar may request to participate as guests, and will be enrolled in the 200 level seminar in the following year upon their request. We will contact you individually if we believe it is not in your best interest to continue to PRx 200 at this time. 

Students completing the 100 level of PRx may also choose to enroll in the new year-long class being offered for the first time in fall 2015 - PHLC 200 Pre-Health Learning Community. This class is a combined pre-health community and you can opt into sections for targeted information in your field of interest as well as exploring other healthcare professions.  This is especially valuable if you are still deciding about pharmacy as the best fit for you. 

If you plan to continue to PRx200, you will need to do this assignment to compute your GPA in science courses according to the instructions below. Also, find your current overall GPA in the NEST.  Enter both in this survey. Your information is confidential; no names are used and only the instructors assigned to the course have access to this information. 

Science GPA computation

  1. Using the Excel spreadsheet tool available in this module, enter grade information on the science courses you have completed. It is best to download the spreadsheet to use; there are two worksheets - one is an example and the other is blank for you to fill in. (In PharmCAS, this includes classes in these subject areas: 
    • Biochemistry
    • Biology
    • Inorganic Chemistry - General Chem
    • Microbiology
    • Organic Chemistry
    • Other Science
    • Physics
  2. Enter the letter grade earned, the GPA points for that letter grade (see key), and number of credit hours completed. 
  3. If you have taken any of these courses away from Creighton, you should still enter them into the spreadsheet with the grade earned at the other institution.  
  4. Note that you enter both instances for any courses repeated. PharmCAS includes all grades in GPA computations. 
  5. As you enter the information, there will be a GPA calculation at the end of the spreadsheet.  Make a note of this for your records and enter it here. 
  6. Save the spreadsheet to keep track of your ongoing science GPA. 
  7. PharmCAS also figures a Math GPA, and a Non-Science GPA.  For this assignment we will just compute the Science GPA.

Overall Creighton GPA  

You can find your current overall Creighton GPA by logging into the NEST. 

  1. Click on Student Services.
  2. Click on Student Records.
  3. Click on Academic Transcript. (You can also see your overall GPA in a Degree Evaluation).
  4. Click on “View Unofficial Transcript.” 
  5. Look for the transcript totals section for your current overall GPA.
  6. Make a note of this for your records and enter it into the survey in the assignment in BlueLine.  

Science course progression

Please select the appropriate response regarding completion of science courses. You may have only completed a few of these courses; it is NOT expected that you would have completed them all.

Quiz 4 will cover

  • Material from the Kinetics Experiment

The quiz will include at least one question derived from the following:

  • (Rate laws for the next three, related, questions should be written in the general form of rate=k[A]x[B]y)
  • (a) What is the form of the full rate law for the reaction between blue food coloring and bleach?
  • (b) In this experiment, we made sure that [NaOCl]>>[Blue Food Coloring], which allows us to (reasonably) assume that [NaOCl] is constant over the course of the experiment, and simplify the rate law you reported in part (a) to something we could study in the lab.  What is this simplifed rate law?
  • (c) How are these rate laws related? (Hint: how is k'(which should appear in part b) related to k (from part a)?)
  • One group of students decided to investigate the effect of [Bleach] on the reaction.  After determining the order with respect to [Blue Food Coloring] as described in the lab manual, they performed two additional trials.   They performed essentially the same experiment except that in one trial they added 5.0 mL of bleach and 5.0 mL water to the 100 mL of blue food coloring, and in the 2nd trial they added 10.0 mL of bleach to 100 mL of blue food coloring.  They plotted ln[Blue Food Coloring] vs. time for both trials and determined the slopes of the lines.  The found that the slope of the 2nd plot (10.0 mL of bleach) was four times as negative as the slope of the first plot (5.0 mL bleach + 5.0 mL water). 
  • (a)  What is the order of the reaction with respect to NaOCl?
  • (b)  What is the purpose of adding 5.0 mL of water in addition to the 5.0 mL of bleach in the first additional trial?

THE ESSAY TOPIC WILL BE PROVIDED BY THE INSTRUCTOR

 

WRITE YOUR ESSAY IN YOUR OWN WORD PROCESSING PROGRAM AND THEN PASTE IT INTO THE TEXT ENTRY AREA PROVIDED HERE. MAKE SURE TO KEEP A COPY OF YOUR WORK.

See Writing Guidelines for details on citing sources and matters of style. Use your own words. Write clearly, Get to the point. Provide evidence and argument to support your ideas.

data.assign_desc:
Experiment 5: Hydrogenation of Alkenes

Video link for this experiment:

mms://winstream.creighton.edu/jtf52615/CHM322Exp6.wmv

Note: The expt. title and content of the video are correct; ignore the numbering in the video (expt. 6, instead of expt. 5), which is from a previous version of the lab manual.

 Write your pre-lab report as per the order of items on the rubric. A flowchart is not required. The material below is only provides clarification.

 Table of reagents

You should complete the Table of Reagents and calculations therein (including theoretical yield) as per the mass of oleic acid you expect to begin with. As you are not expected to be able to weigh that exact same amount of oleic acid in lab, you should include the exact mass of oleic acid and that of the affected reagents in the 'observations' part of your procedure.

 Include the following information in the form of a table, with safety warnings for each. Safety warnings for two of them have been provided for you.

Oleic acid - mass, MW, moles, structure

10% Pd/C – mass only (Safety hazard: Irritant, flammable solid)

Ammonium formate - mass, MW, moles, structure

Methanol - quantity, MW, density

Dichloromethane: quantity, MW, density

95% ethyl alcohol (same as used in expt. 4): quantity, MW, density

1M Sulfuric acid: quantity (Safety hazard: Corrosive)

 Product: stearic acid – structure, MW, moles and melting point.

 Show the theoretical yield calculation in a separate step as indicated on the rubric. Keep in mind when calculating the theoretical yield that Pd/C is NOT the limiting reagent.

 --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

How to calculate mass of ammonium formate needed:

Multiply the moles of oleic acid by 4; this gives you the moles of ammonium formate needed.

Multiply moles of ammonium formate from the above step by its molecular weight, to determine grams of ammonium formate to be used in the experiment.

data.assign_desc:
Please write up the video idea for your #TheRealCreighton video. The explanation of your idea should be around 200 words. Here are a few examples of what these ideas can look like:

 

#TheRealCreighton: Party Patty

The video opens with scenes of Patty at a Creighton soccer game with her friends. Scores of Creighton students yell and cheer for their favorite players. We see Patty getting called onto the field for a beanbag toss during halftime. She laughs as she throws beanbags. Her friends cheer. We see additional images of the soccer team scoring and winning during the closing moments of the game. Then, we see Patty leaving the stadium with her friends Sarah and Justine. They walk to the Slowdown. We see them get their hands stamped at the door. Inside, a DJ plays and young people dance. Patty dances with her friends. We see a progressive series of still images that zoom in on Patty’s watch. Time passes: 11:30, 12:30, 1:45, 2:30a. A progressive series of still shots zoom out. We watch Patty and her friends leave the bar and walk back to campus. We see a final picture of the girls walking toward the horizon, campus fluorescently lit up in the distance.

 

Creighton: The place where you’ll make friends for a lifetime.

 

#TheRealCreighton: Smiling Jim

The video opens with Jim, the smiling sophomore. Jim is in bed. We hear the sound of his alarm clock going off. The clock reads: 4:45am. Though it is early in the morning, Jim is smiling. We see images of Jim smiling as he exits his dorm, gets into his car, and goes to rowing practice. He continues to smile even as he is sweating, rowing sprints at practice. He smiles at breakfast when he is sitting near his friends. He continues to smile after breakfast during a 3-hour chemistry lecture. We see him smiling as he naps on one of the couches in Reinert, a chemistry book propped up on his chest. He is smiling when he wakes up to go to BLUJ radio to host his radio show. He is smiling while he eats dinner and when he returns to his room in order to study for three hours before going to bed. We see him before he goes to sleep, smiling in bed. A picture of Jim smiling in bed fades into a text slide: 

 

Creighton: It’s so great that you’ll even smile when you’re stressed.

 

While your brainstorming should be creative, it should also be practicable. In other words, you should brainstorm a video idea that you could actually create without incurring significant expense in technological, travel, or production costs.

 

Once you post your idea, you will be able to see your peers' ideas.

data.assign_desc:
1.  All of the pairings are correct except for: C. peristalsis--a serous membrane that lines the abdominopelvic cavity and covers organs.  Peristalsis is the muscle contraction in the gut.  Peritoneum is a serous membrane that lines the abdominopelvic cavity and covers organs.

2.  True: digestion involves ingestion, transport of food for chemical and mechanical breakdown into small molecules that can be transported across the lining of the digestive tract to the blood.

3.  A.  The stomach is divided into 4 parts, the cardia, fundus, body and pylorus (not tail).  B. The pyloric sphincter is the circular smooth muscle that controls the movement from pylorus into duodenum.  C. Rugae are not permanent folds of gastric mucosa, they flatten out as the stomach fills up. So, B is the answer.  

4.  The length of the small intestine (20 feet) and large intestine (8 feet) is not 10 feet. False.

5.  All of the statements about the wall of the digestive tract are true except for B.  There are motor and sensory nerves in the wall of the digestive tract (to sense stretch and to cause contraction of smooth muscle).

6..All of the parings were correct except for B, chief cells secrete pepsinogen, they do not control the secretions of the other gastric cells.

7.  Most of the absorption in the small intestines takes place in the duodenum.  False, most of the absorption takes place in the jejunum.

8.  The correct pathway of filtrate was given in choice C: renal corpuscle, proximal convoluted tubule, loop of Henle, distal convoluted tubule, collecting system.

9.  The kidneys do produce 180 liters of filtrate a day.  Boom.

10.  The renal corpuscle consists of all the listed options, so the answer is D.

data.assign_desc:
1.  B. The sacrum is part of the axial skeleton, not the appendicular skeleton.

2.  C. The lower limb has tarsals and metatarsals.  The upper extremity has carpals and metacarpals.

3.  D. The femur has a greater and lesser trochanter and the humerus has a greater and lesser tubercle.

4.  C. Myofilaments do not shorten during a contraction, they slide past one another.

5.  A. Synovial joints have the most movement of all the joints and have capsules, synovial membranes and articular cartilages.

6.  False. The male pelvis has a smaller pubic angle than a female pelvis.

7.  True. Movement does occur at both the IV disks and the between the inferior and superior articular facets.

8.  C. The rotator cuff is made of the supraspinatus, the infraspinatus, teres minor and subscapularis.

9.  True. Thick filaments are made of myosin and attach in the center of the sarcomere at the M line.

10.  2./B. Protraction/retraction does not occur at the glenohumeral joint, but at the sternoclavicular joint.

data.assign_desc:
While we've read Frankl's Man's Search for Meaning, we have been asking two basic questions:

1) What is Frankl's life philosophy?

2) How can I use Frankl's philosophy in order to gain a better sense of my life's purpose?

 

We have also been discussing and analyzing the arguments (from families, peer groups, cultures, economies, and architectures) that influence our self-perception and decision making and/or that make our decisions more difficult.

During this assignment, I would like you to think about the arguments (broadly conceived) in your life that have detracted from your sense of purpose, fulfillment, and happiness. What arguments from social, cultural, or physical entities have impeded your progress toward realizing your life's work and your sense of (ultimate) meaning? I am not asking you to think about happiness/fulfillment in the conventional sense (money, prestige, power, etc.) - but rather in Frankl's sense: a goal-driven activity that gives your life its substance and structure.

Please describe two of these arguments (and their sources) in 200-250 words each. Please note that I am not asking you to write a formal essay but rather to brainstorm regarding forces in your life that have threatened your sense of meaning.

 

Your responses to this prompt are 100% confidential, but keep in mind that you will eventually write an essay for this project that may be peer reviewed during the drafting/revising process.

 

Email me with questions about this prompt - or if you have any other questions about Frankl and our current work in the class.
data.assign_title: Long Response #4: Arguments That Detract from Your Fulfillment/Life's Purpose

data.assign_desc:
Quiz 2 will cover

  • Material from the Intermolecular Forces Experiment

The quiz will include at least one questions derived from the following:

  • The temperature change seen in this experiment is due to "evaporative cooling" - the energy that is required to break the intermolecular forces comes from the other molecules, resulting in a decrease in temperature.  In Organic Chemistry, you will use a "rotovap" - a device that reduces the pressure over a sample in order to remove the solvent.  Most rotovaps have a water bath to keep the temperature constant.  What would happen to the temperature if you were not able to use the water bath (i.e. you had no way of keeping the temp constant)?  Be able to explain your answer.  (Consider the relationship between vapor pressure, external pressure and boiling/evaporation.  Ch. 10.5 of your textbook may be useful.)
  • Is the process of evaporation endothermic or exothermic?  How do you know?
  • Explain why weaker overall intermolecular forces lead to a greater change in temperature than stronger intermolecular forces.

data.assign_desc:
During unit #1, we helped to define Creighton’s identity through a video/Twitter campaign that summarizes different aspects of Creighton’s ethos through a compelling narrative. In this project, you will write to articulate your own identity by considering your existential purpose. This unit will ask you to answer the question: What are the arguments – broadly conceived – that you’ve encountered in the course of your life that have impeded your progress to realizing your life’s purpose? Why are these arguments persuasive, and in what ways are they erroneous or deceptive? To help us understand the scope of these questions, we will read Man’s Search for Meaning, which was written by a psychiatrist and philosopher named Victor Frankl, who survived the Holocaust to found a new school of psychoanalysis known as logotherapy.

We will also study argumentative fallacies in public culture in an attempt to understand the ways that we are influenced by various media. Finally each student will write a 1,750-2,000-word essay that describes one erroneous, wrongheaded, or deceptive public or private argument. In the essay, students will answer three main questions:

 

Section #1: What argument has impeded your progress toward realizing your life’s purpose? What is the social context for that argument? In other words, where and how has that argument manifested in your life?

 

Section #2: Did/does your understanding of the argument change your opinion about it? Will/has this understanding changed the way you act/plan to act in the future? Why or why not?

 

Section #3: What would Victor Frankl say about this argument? What advice would Frankl give based on our reading of Man’s Search for Meaning? Optional: What advice would the creators of the Happy documentary likely provide regarding this argument?

 

 

For homework on 3/26, you should write Section #3 of your paper, and you should submit your whole essay (Sections 1-3) here. See Dr. Prenosil's example essay for a model of how this essay might look:

Day Eighteen_Unit #2_Sample Essayv1.9_Full_For Students.docx

data.assign_desc: One of your friends has a crush on a guy named Sam, a popular student who is a strong leader on campus and who has a winning smile. You’ve worked with Sam on a student committee, and you’ve enjoyed your interaction with him. One night at a party, Sam and your friend become intoxicated and end up sleeping in the same room at another friend’s apartment. The following week, your friend seems sad and distant. You ask her if she’s feeling Ok, and she replies that “everything’s fine” and changes the topic. But, as days and weeks pass, she seems increasingly withdrawn. Further, she has missed every student committee meeting where Sam would normally be present. And you noticed that when you mentioned your friend’s name to Sam recently, he wouldn’t look you in the eye. You’ve talked to some of your other peers who knew your friend in high school, and it seems that your friend has a history of depression and anxiety. Your friend looks like she’s losing weight, and you’re really concerned about her wellbeing. How should you proceed in this situation?

IMPORTANT:

This experiment is designed to teach you fundamental practical lab skills that can only be mastered by practice.  To make sure that there is enough equipment for each student to practice, and to ensure that we can provide you with any help needed, you will each have been assigned to come to lab for an 80 minute shift.

  • Stations 1-6:  come to the first half of lab (3:30 (Sections BB and EE) or 5:00 (Sections HH and KK))
  • Stations 7:12:  come to the second half of lab (5:00 (Sections BB and EE) or 6:30 (Sections HH and KK))

You must come directly to the lab at your assigned time.  There will be no pre-lab lecture.  Instead, the techniques being used will be demonstrated to you in small groups at each station.  If you arrive late, you will miss some of the demonstrations, and have less time to complete the three stations, both of which put you at a disadvantage.  If you arrive at a time other than the one you are assigned to, you will only be allowed to complete the experiments if there is room, and may receive a point deduction on your lab work grade.  If you have a good reason for wanting to attend the other time, TALK TO ME - I will accommodate you if I can. ask around - you are welcome to switch times with someone assigned to the "other" time (so the total number of students in each stays the same).

Before lab, you should...

  • Read the entire experiment (including all parts of the Introduction and Procedure).
    • Mark up your lab manual with any notes or questions you may have!  No introduction is necessary.
  • Watch this video to familiarize yourself with the use of a volumetric pipette (a TA will also demonstrate in-person):

Link

  • Watch this video on the proper use of a Mohr pipette.  (A TA will also demonstrate in-person.)

By the end of lab, you should...

  • Be comfortable reading burettes (this skill will be necessary for the lab two weeks later, as well as frequently used in future semesters).

data.assign_desc:
Reminder: There is no pre-lab quiz for Experiment 3.

On the assignment sheet you received in lab:

1. "Solubility at 23 deg C" simply means solubility at room temperature.

2. Extracts into 1M NaOH?

Y = Yes - it reacts with and dissolves in NaOH (if it's a carboxylic acid), or simply dissolves in NaOH

N = No - it neither reacts with nor dissolves in NaOH

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Pre-laboratory assignment: 

Complete section I (Introduction) as per the rubric.

For section II (Procedure and Observations):

A flowchart is required. You may use the flowchart on page 70 of the lab manual as an example. Draw the flowchart on a fresh page in your lab note book (before writing the procedure). This page must only contain the flowchart.

Start the numbered, step-wise procedure on the next page.

Clearly indicate your assigned sample number on your lab report (look for it on the top right corner of your assignment sheet) . Use the solubility information from the sheet provided that is relevant for your assigned components.

For purification of isolated components:

1. Only camphor should be purified by sublimation.

2. If salicylic acid is one of your assigned compounds, it can be purified using the same recrystallization procedure (with 45 mL of water per gram of salicylic acid) as done in Expt. 2.

3. ALL other compounds should be purified by recrystallization using the solvent from the "recrystallizes from" column on your assignment sheet. In the procedure that you write, replace the word "solvent" in the following paragraph with the name of the solvent you will use.

Transfer the isolated compound to a 50 mL Erlenmeyer flask. Add ~15 mL of solvent and boiling chips. Heat the solution on a hot plate until the solid completely dissolves. If the solid does not dissolve, add ~3 mL of solvent and bring to a boil again. Repeat this process till you have added just enough solvent to dissolve the solid. Remove from heat and cool to room temperature until crystals start to form, .then place in an ice-water bath until there is no appreciable change in the mass of crystals formed. Collect the crystals by vacuum filtration.

---------------------------------------- End of pre-lab assignment---------------------------------------------------

 Important notes:

1. Both the components of your assigned mixture are solids. You will have the same reagents available in lab as you did in Expt. 2.

 2. DO NOT suggest a procedure for the separation of components using water as a solvent. The fact that a compound is insoluble or sparingly soluble in water is of relevance only while recovering it in an aqueous solution as you did for salicylic acid (Part C in Expt.2.).

 3. If it is possible for you to perform the separation of the two assigned components using only one liquid (CH2Cl2 or 1M NaOH), be advised that you cannot use a separatory funnel in this case. To use a sep funnel, you must have two (immsicible) liquid layers.

 4. Filtration:

As discussed in pre-lab lecture:

If you are filtering an organic solvent (CH2Cl2), you must use gravity filtration.

If you are filtering water/an aqueous phase, you must use vacuum filtration. 

 5. You cannot rotavap water /an aqueous phase.  

6. Never add conc. HCl to an organic phase.

7. You do not need to look up the densities of the solids that you are trying to separate – only the densities of the liquids (same reagents used in expt. 2) are relevant in this experiment.

data.assign_desc:
The School is committed to enabling students with disabilities to complete the course of study of the OTD Program by means of reasonable accommodations consistent with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). These technical standards articulate the expectations and requisite abilities considered essential for occupational therapy students to become primary providers of occupational therapy services. All students admitted to the Doctor of Occupational Therapy (OTD) Program should be able to demonstrate these abilities at the time of admission and at all times during their matriculation.

Observation / Sensory
Students must have sufficient visual abilities to be able to observe and interpret patients/clients accurately. They should also possess functional tactile and proprioceptive skills and abilities necessary to perceive and synthesize inputs during patient/client interaction, evaluation, and treatment.

Communication
Students must demonstrate effective verbal and written communication with patients, family members/caregivers, faculty/staff, fieldwork preceptors, payers, elected officials, members of the healthcare team and others. They must demonstrate appropriate communication with people of different ages and genders, with diverse physical, cognitive and emotional abilities, and from different cultural, ethnic, racial, socioeconomic, and religious backgrounds and lifestyles. Students must demonstrate the ability to use therapeutic communication and a client centered approach. They must display adequate English language skills in written and oral communication.

Motor
Students must display adequate motor skills to provide safe, efficient, and effective occupational therapy treatment. Examples of motor skills include sitting tolerance, splint or assisted technology fabrication, computer usage, performing transfers and assisting with bed mobility, and providing range of motion and strengthening activities. These motor skills require adequate gross and fine motor function, vestibular function, strength, and functional usage of the sensory system.

Intellectual / Conceptual
Students must demonstrate problemsolving throughout the didactic and experiential components of the program. This includes the ability to interpret information from multiple sources (written, verbal, environmental, interpersonal, etc.), carry out instructions in a timely manner, and understand and follow policies and procedures. Therefore, the student must be able to read complex material, and write in a way that is accurate, descriptive, free from errors and consistent with guidelines or standards. Further, students must be able to apply critical thinking processes in order to gather information, identify problems and alternative plans of action, and make decisions spontaneously, in "on the spot" situations, frequently under pressure from multiple workload, time and variable environmental demands.

Behavioral / Social Skills / Professionalism Students must posses sufficient emotional health to fully utilize their intellectual abilities, exercise good judgment, adhere to ethical standards, complete patient care responsibilities promptly, and relate to others with courtesy, compassion, maturity, and respect for their dignity. Because occupational therapy education and practice takes place in a large variety of settings, students must have the ability to participate collaboratively as a (professional) team member, must be able to modify behavior in response to feedback, and display emotional health when faced with changing environments, clinical uncertainties, and stressful workloads that include multiple concurrent demands and short deadlines. This requires the ability of students to be aware of and appropriately react to their own emotional responses. In addition, students must at all times maintain personal appearance and hygiene that is appropriate for professional and classroom settings.

Attainment of Technical Standards
Inability to comply with these technical standards may result in course failure. Applicants are encouraged to voluntarily discuss their disabilities with the Director of Admissions and the Assistant / Associate Dean for Academic Affairs of the School in order to consider and prepare for the accommodations that may be needed. After enrollment, a student with a disability who wishes to request reasonable accommodations may directly contact the Assistant / Associate Dean for Academic Affairs of the School or the Creighton University Office of Services for Students with Disabilities. Verification and documentation of the disability by a qualified professional, such as a physician or psychologist, will be needed before reasonable accommodations are made. Accommodations will not be considered reasonable if they affect the substance of the occupational therapy educational program, compromise the School’s educational standards, and/or negatively affect the safety of students and/or other people, including patients, with whom they may come into contact in the course of their studies. If accommodations are provided, this information will be kept in strict confidence.

All occupational therapy applicants must review the technical standards described in this document and perform a self-evaluation to determine if they are able to maintain compliance with them. 

View the PDF version
Do not sign and return form as requested.

Once you have read the material, take the quiz at the bottom of this page.

See the following resources for intellectual property, bibliographic, and citation information:

LP_Day Twenty Five.pptx

 

UPDATE: Please submit your whole Wikipedia article (including your bibliography) here either via text entry or as a Word document by 7pm on Thursday, April 30th.

UPDATE: For the homework on 4/23: please write an additional 400-500 words on your Wikipedia article. Submit your 400-500 words as an addition to this dropbox.

 

This response has two components:

 

1) Please think about your topic and select 5-7 "headings" or sections under which you can group your text. List those headings here in bold.

For example, the article on authentic leadership from Thursday's class had the following headings:

  • 1 Historical Background
  • 2 Definitions
    • 2.1 Authenticity and ethics
    • 2.2 Patterns of behavior
  • 3 Empirical model of authentic leadership
    • 3.1 Antecedents
    • 3.2 Mediators
    • 3.3 Consequences
  • 4 Measures
    • 4.1 Leader Authenticity Scale (LAS)
    • 4.2 Authentic Leadership Questionnaire (ALQ)
    • 4.3 Authentic Leadership Inventory (ALI)
    • 4.4 Authenticity Inventory (AI:3)
  • 5 Becoming an authentic leader
  • 6 Relationship to other leadership theories
  • 7 Future research
  • 8 Further reading
  • 9 See also
  • 10 References
  • 11 External links

 

Note: your headings will necessarily change as you learn more about your topic. You are not committing to these headings permanently. They will serve as a starting place for planning your article. 

 

2) Please write 500 words of your Wikipedia article, keeping in mind the citation style appropriate to Wikipedia articles. For web-based content, you should cite the content as:

(authorlastname)

Paginated content (content with page numbers) should be cited as:

(authorlastname: #)

 

Email Dr. Prenosil with questions--

Alumni Want to be Your Mentors - Sign Up Today!

Dear Members of Creighton’s Pharm.D. Class of 2020, DPT Class of 2019 and OTD Class of 2019,

Congratulations on your acceptance into the Creighton University School of Pharmacy and Health Professions! As a member of the 2016 entering class, you are invited to apply to participate in our Alumni-Student Mentor Program.

Complete the online application to apply for the Alumni-Student Mentor Program.

Preference in the matching process will be given to students who submit an application by noon Friday, August 12, 2016.

The program offers a limited number of Creighton DPT, OTD and Pharm.D. students the opportunity to develop a mentoring relationship with an alumnus/ae who wants to share his/her educational and professional experiences to help Creighton students achieve greater success in their academic and professional pursuits. 

Now in its third year, the program boots more than 285 successful matches.  It is coordinated through the School’s Alumni Advisory Board and designed to be flexible enough so that mentoring and professional relationship-building can be accomplished face-to-face and/or via distance online throughout the student’s academic career…and beyond. More information on the program, including details on when matches will be announced, can be found at https://spahp.creighton.edu/alumni/getting-involved/alumni-mentoring-program.

The SPAHP Alumni Advisory Board will have a table at the campus Resource Fair, so be sure to stop by. We look forward to welcoming you this fall and hope you consider applying to become a mentee.  Please email spahparo@creighton.edu or call 402.280.4742 with any questions.

Sincerely,

Art Farha, RPh, BSPha’70
Past Chair, Alumni Advisory Board
School of Pharmacy and Health Professions

Curt Barr, RPh, Pharm.D., BSPha'74
Assistant Dean for Alumni Relations
School of Pharmacy and Health Professions

data.assign_desc:
Answer each of the following 5 questions in complete sentences. Avoid trying to bullet or diagram as the changes in formatting when you save the answer will change the way it looks on the page. Your answer for each question should be under 300 words. Each question is worth 20 points.

1. Using either the topic of the presentation you made in class or the issue of obesity, identify your personal health beliefs and the reasons you have that belief. In what ways are your beliefs different from and similar to the beliefs of a different group? Based on the strengths and weaknesses of the reasons people have for holding both sets of beliefs, how have your beliefs changed on this issue?

2. Define the concept of “social justice.” Based on the issue of your photovoice presentation, how do social conditions and/or social pressures prevent some people from achieving our health and wellness goals?

3. What does “human dignity” mean to you? Based on the presentation made by one of the other students in your class (NOT your own presentation) explain how social privilege or power undermined human dignity or was used to promote human dignity.

4. Images in popular media have the potential to shape our attitudes, beliefs, and behaviors concerning health and illness. Based on the film The Fault in Our Stars, identify three examples where the film uses images that may create inaccurate or harmful beliefs or behaviors in a viewer. Explain why you believe these images may lead to inaccurate or harmful beliefs and why the images were used in the film. Identify two instances where the film uses images that may create accurate or helpful beliefs or behaviors in a viewer. Explain why you believe these images may result in accurate or helpful beliefs and why the images were used in the film.

5. Define each of the elements of the Health Belief Model (perceived severity, perceived susceptibility, perceived benefits, perceived costs, and perceived efficacy). Using examples from one or more health promotion messages, explain how the message (or messages) uses each of the four Message Components from the Health Belief Model to target a specific belief and change that belief. Identify the intended health behaviors that the message or messages will produce.

data.assign_desc:
1.  The autonomic nervous system is organized differently from the somatic nervous, system, has preganglionic neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem and postganglionic neurons located in ganglia.  It does not include voluntary motor neurons in the cerebral cortex.

2.  Your autonomic nervous system does control your vital physiological functions without your conscious participation (TRUE).

3.  The parasympathetic division of the ANS includes preganglionic axons that are part of cranial nerves III, VII,  IX and X. All the other options were false.

4.  Sympathetic preganlionic neuron cell bodies are located in the spinal cord between T1-L2.  (TRUE)

5.  Sympathetic axons do not travel in the vagus nerve to innvervate viscera. (the vagus nerve contains parasympathetic axons).

6.  This question was matching pre-and post ganglioinc axons with their neurotransmitter.  The one false option was sympathetic preganglionic axons do not release norepinephrine (they release acetylcholine).  Therefore that was the correct answer.

7.  A receptive field is the area monitored by a sensory receptor.  (TRUE)

8.  Hair cells are not an example of a general sensory receptor (they are special sensory receptors).  

9.  Baroreceptors are not sensitive to oxygen, carbon dioxide and pH.  Chemoreceptors are sensitive to these stimuli..

10.  Activity in the vestibular system is not responsible for our ability to hear. We hear because of activity in our auditory system.

Good luck!

Creighton University is committed to the safety of all students. Please see the information below about resources available to students.

Creighton University is committed to caring for each member of the community as part of our Jesuit identity. An integral part of this commitment is understanding the university policies that protect students, faculty, and staff from harassment and discrimination. The following video will cover on-going violence prevention efforts at the University, the Sexual Violence, Harassment, Discrimination, and Grievance policy, how to report an incident to the university, and what resources are available to you. The presenter, Allison Taylor, M.Ed. works in the Office of Equity and Inclusion at Creighton University.

To report sexual violence, harassment or discrimination please use the online reporting form located on the Office of Equity and Inclusion website or call 402-280-3189. If you would like more information before making a report or are interested in advocacy services, please contact the Violence Intervention and Prevention Center at 402-280-3794. The VIP Center can assist distance students with information on protection orders, filing police reports, safety planning, and gaining access to local resources in your community.

View the video now

data.assign_desc:
-ing PROJECT

RSP Fall 2014

This project is designed for you to get to know your classmates and life at Creighton. You will be assigned to a group of 3-4 individuals. As a group, you will need to engage in 7 activities that require your group to spend time with each other. Your group needs to document (take pictures of) itself " ____-ing" together.

Every group needs to participate in "eating" and "Jesuit-ing." The other 5 -ing activities are your choice. You should also come up with a group name (this does not count as an –ing activity).

Be creative in choosing your activities and remember they should be something active that end in "-ing" (and also should not be dangerous, illegal, sexual or profane in anyway). Each group member must appear in each picture, no photoshop, please!

You will then take all of your "-ing" activities and put them together in a visual presentation to show your RSP class on Tuesday September 30th. Please submit the powerpoint or visual aid to this dropbox. All group members must participate in the presentation of your activities. Presentations can be fairly informal, but should be 3-10 minutes in length.

data.assign_desc:
1.  Epithelial tissues line surfaces, are avascular and have some amount of barrier function.  They do not have much extracellular space.

2.  Connective tissues are the most diverse of the tissues, are characterized by cells surrounded by abundant extracellular matrix and protect, support and are a source of energy.  They are not necessarily arranged in sheets and layers (like epithelial tissues).

3.  There are 3 types of cartilage in the body.  Fibrous cartilage is found in IV disks and menisci and hyaline cartilage lines the articulating surfaces of bone. Elastic cartilage has the ability to stretch and return to its original shape.

4.  Skeletal muscle is voluntary, striated muscle.  Cardiac muscle is striated involuntary muscle.  Smooth muscle is non-striated and involuntary muscle.

5.  Bad question.  Everybody got this correct.

6.  Thin skin has hair follicles and sweat glands.

7.  Melanocytes are pigmented cells that are found in stratum basale, and to a lesser extent stratum spinosum.

8.  Dermis is made up mostly dense irregular connective tissue, with a relatively thin layer of loose connective tissue.  It provides the skin with tensile strength and elasticity, contains blood vessels, sensory receptors and sweat glands. Aging has a negative effect on skin properties.

9.  Melanoma is less common but more dangerous than basal cell carcinoma.

10.  Epithelial, connective, muscle, nervous.

data.assign_desc:
Patient counseling standards originally were set in the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 (OBRA 1990), which is a law mandating that pharmacists offer counseling to patients regarding their prescriptions.  If the patient accepts this offer, pharmacists should discuss the following:

  • Name of medication
  • Intended use and expected action
  • Route, dosage form, dosage, and administration schedule
  • Proper storage
  • Common adverse effects that may be encountered
  • Techniques for self-monitoring of drug therapy
  • Prescription refill information
  • Action to take if a dose is missed
  • Potential drug–drug or drug–food interactions or other therapeutic contraindications

Although the law was intended for Medicaid patients, individual states adopted rules to make counseling applicable to other patients, as well. Thus, counseling is one of the tools that may be used to provide MTM services. One of the limitations of counseling, however, is that information generally is provided in a one-way, provider-centered manner (i.e., pharmacist to patient or pharmacist to caregiver). Instead, the pharmacist should ask questions to elicit needed information from the patient to fill the medication(s) in question and also to ensure that all of the patient's medications are providing optimal benefit.

Before your counseling session, please review Patient Counseling information under the Resources Module.  This includes the Patient Counseling Checklist, the Patient Counseling Videos, and the Patient Counseling PowerPoint in the BlueCast, so you know what to expect.

 

List of Medications:

Medication           Electronic Prescription
Atorvastatin Atorvastatin Prescription
Memantine Memantine Prescription
Metformin Metformin Prescription
Ropinirole Ropinirole Prescription

data.assign_desc:
Experiment 1: Distillation

 Attach the same rubric (from your pre-lab assignment) to your post-lab assignment. If you don't have it, simply print a new one!

Here’s what to include in your post-lab part of the report:                   

 II. Procedure and Observations

- graph* of boiling point vs. drops collected for parts A and B

- data table and graph* of boiling point vs. drops for part C

* Graphs may be hand-drawn or computer generated, with axes labeled appropriately and units included.

 III. Conclusions

a) Parts A and B: analyze results and efficiency of the distillation techniques used

b) Part C: Clearly indicate sample code; state observed b.pts. from graph; identify the two liquids in the unknown mixture

IV. Summary Questions

 1. Calculate the mole fraction of each component in a mixture containing 4.50 mL each of toluene and cyclohexane. Show your work! (3)

 2. Explain using chemical bonding and polarity concepts why the boiling point of water (100 °C) is much higher than that of hexane (69 °C). Draw structures and show relevant bonds. (3)

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

NOTE: Section III (Conclusion) must be hand-written in ink in your lab notebook. % yield calculations are not applicable to this experiment.

Section IV (Summary Questions) can be answered either in your lab notebook or on a separate sheet of paper, and can hand-written or typed/printed out.

data.assign_desc:
The primary topics in this chapter, use of language and presentational aids, ask you to consider how choices of representation can change not only what you are saying in your presentation, but also how your audience perceives and evaluates the topic, your presentation, and you, the speaker.

One simple way to consider this point is to think about the differences in using the terms “beach” and “shore” in describing the place where land meets water. Each describes a similar and related phenomenon but the perspective each brings to mind (one invoking warm sand under your feet and the other a rocking boat) shapes the way you think about it. Additionally, if you were to try to represent each visually or through sound, you might produce very different photographs, models, figures, audio recordings and the like to do so.

This assignment has three steps.

STEP 1: In your initial post, find or make a representation (audio, video, photo) that you believe is representative of the topic of immigration. Please watch this video which shows how to upload an image using Blueline (Links to an external site.)  Upload the representation. If you are not the source of this representation, provide an appropriate APA 6th citation under the representation.

 

STEP 2: Then write and describe in your own words how you would present this visual aid to your audience. Use language techniques recommended in Chapter 5. Keep in mind that representing people as “illegal aliens” vs. “undocumented workers” could influence your audience’s perception of your topic and illustrate your personal attitudes toward the topic. Also, considering the range of technologies available, what would be the most effective way to present this representation in your actual presentation? What would be the least effective way to present the representation in your presentation?

 

STEP 3: In your replies to two of your group members, discuss how their initial posts represent this visual image through language.

  1.     How would the audience perceive the speaker’s use of visual aids and language? Is the speaker more objective, informed, and unbiased about immigration than the others?
  2.     What language choices would you make for characterizing immigration, the people who have immigrated to the United States (legal and not), and any laws or policies that would shape immigration in the future?
  3.     Which of your shared representations in a speech on immigration would be most be the most persuasive?

data.assign_desc:
In addition to the commercial background check through Verified Credentials, Inc., students in the Alaska pathway are required to complete a criminal background check through the state of Alaska, as required by health care facilities in Alaska. Please note that many facilities in Alaska require employees to complete both a state of Alaska background check and a commercial background check. This will be the case for students, as well, since you will have labs and fieldwork experiences at these facilities. Please follow the instructions carefully, as there are many details involved in this process.

The purpose of this requirement is to help ensure the public and patient safety. It will also assure you as a Creighton University student that you meet the minimum background screening requirements for employment prior to devoting your time and money to secure a degree. Healthcare facilities today are becoming very cautious in terms of their hiring practices not only to protect their patients, but also to protect the hospital. ALL STUDENTS MUST COMPLETE THIS PROCESS.

Providence Alaska has a requirement that all individuals working at our healthcare facilities, including students, undergo a background check through the Alaska State Department of Health and Human Services Background Check Unit.  I have attached the information and forms necessary for this process.  Please note:  The Background Check Unit requires that all documents, fingerprints, and fees be submitted to their office within 30 days of the online application.  If there are any missing documents, fingerprints, or fees, the application will be cancelled.  You will need to reapply and resubmit all fees and documents again and the original fees will not be refunded.   For more details read THIS 

The Process Step 1: Providence Orientation Forms DUE FRI AUG 5

During your educational program you will have opportunities to engage in lab activities and other immersion experiences at Providence Health and Service Alaska (Providence).  All occupational therapy students in Alaska are required to complete this training for Providence Health.

A representative from Providence will provide you with an orientation to the health system. Prior to this in-person orientation, you are required to complete some readings. Please review the attached materials thoroughly during Welcome Week because there will be a question and answer segment regarding this information during on site orientation. You may wish to print the attachments and have them available as references.

For any questions about this process, please contact Amanda Kratochvil, Providence Alaska Learning Institute, Anchorage, AK; Phone: 907-212-3011; Email: Amanda.Kratochvil@providence.org

Complete these forms and turn into the AK Background Check and Providence Orientation submission folder by Aug 5th.

  1. Student Information and Release 2016
  2. NABCS ROI form

The Process Step 2: Providence Orientation Prep  DUE AUG 25

ONSITE ORIENTATION IS SCHEDULED FOR AUGUST 25 FROM 1-3 PM AT the Providence Region Building at 3760 Piper Street, 2nd Floor.

For any questions about this process, please contact Amanda Kratochvil, Providence Alaska Learning Institute, Anchorage, AK; Phone: 907-212-3011; Email: Amanda.Kratochvil@providence.org

Assigned Readings for Providence Orientation:

  1. Student Orientation Guide 2016
  2. 100 Years of Caring
  3. Rights of Individual Policy
  4. Acceptable Use Policy
  5. PAMCCAMPUS
  6. Creighton OT 2016 – Student orientation Directions

Bring with you: Your government-issued identification

data.assign_desc:
Please refer to the following guidance materials below when preparing your Posters for this contest.

  • Note 1: Do note that it is important to consider Copyright guidelines, as copyright concerns may prevent us from “publishing” your dynamite posters for public access (on such venues as a planned Immunization Resource Toolbox that we are planning for the Pharmacy Group Resources BlueLine Site, or even our Immunization Task Force website here in Nebraska). Such publications are reportable on your Resumes!
  • Note 2: Judy Bergjord, Reference Librarian at the Health Sciences Library contributed to producing these Copyright materials, and can be an excellent resource if you have further questions – 402.280.5138. She also encourages people to take their own pictures to avoid any copyright problem; however warning that when doing so, you should have your subject sign the Photo Release form also provided here. If the individual’s face is not apparent, such Release is not needed.

Resources:

  • Poster Development Guideline
  • OI Poster Judging Rubric (see below)
  • Copyright Guideline for Posters
  • Sample Photo Release Form

….and some Poster Demos to help you get started:

  • General Immunization Promo Poster Demo
  • Pertussis Poster Demo
  • Varicella Poster Demo

Please submit the final version of each poster no later than Friday, October 30th 11:59 CST. There will be no draft submission opportunity and late submissions will not be accepted. Create a pdf version of the final poster draft file to submit for the contest (do a “save as” and use the drop down menu to choose pdf). First save a copy of your final poster draft in Word, and retain in your files in case of future need for editing.  Multiple posters may be submitted to the same portal, just click ‘re-submit assignment’ and upload each document. If the same poster or posters are submitted multiple times, only the most recent versions of each will be judged. Each Poster is worth 2 APhA-ASP honor cord points. Be sure to read over the rubric and copyright guidelines before submitting posters. Poster judging will not begin until after the submission deadline.

Email Jennifer Hunt or Jessica Prior at with any questions about the competition.

Please see the rubric below on how the poster will be scored.  NOTE: Revision required for Category Score <5 in Accuracy, or <3 for other Categories, OR for Overall Score < 15/20

data.assign_desc:
To view a video of Expt.1, access the following file:

mms://winstream.creighton.edu/jtf52615/CHM322EXP1.wmv

 Windows users:  Copy-paste the link into a web browser and the video should open automatically in Windows Media Player (ignore any error messages you may see). Use IE or Firefox (avoid Chrome).

 Mac users:  You will need a WMV media player to access these videos. One free option is Macgo Mac Media Player. Once downloaded and installed, open the program, go to File -> Open URL and type the address listed above into the window to view.

Alternatively, you may download a free VLC media and the video should work.

In the unlikely event that neither of these work, do not pay for any software; instead, try to view it on a PC in the library or elsewhere.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Experiment 1: Distillation

Pre-lab

This assignment must be hand-written in ink in your lab note book. Follow the order of items on the rubric to complete the pre-laboratory assignment. The information provided below is only for clarification purposes. Click here for additional help to write your pre-lab report.

 

 For the Table of reagents, include name, structure, quantity (how much of each chemical you need to perform the experiment), and b.pt. of known liquids from parts A and B of the procedure. Be sure to include safety warnings of chemicals involved. Note: The known liquid mixture (used in parts A and B) contains a 1:1 ratio by volume of toluene and cyclohexane.

 

 There is no overall reaction or theoretical yield calculation associated with this experiment.

 Include labeled set-up diagrams for simple and fractional distillation (p.42 and 43).

 

For the first week of this experiment: You must write the procedure for Parts A and B (pp. 42-43 of the lab manual) as shown under "sample pages" in the syllabus.

On a fresh page, generate a data table to collect data for No. of drops vs Temperature for Part A (simple distillation) and B (fractional distillation). You can expect to collect about 60 drops each for Parts A and B.

 

For the second week of the experiment:  You only need to include the procedure for Part C (p.44).  You do not need to include the unknown components table (p.44).

data.assign_desc:
Please call the phone number in your work station and get 8 transfer prescriptions for your patient.

The information required for a pharmacy prescription transfer is as follows:

    • All basic information from the original prescription
      • Patient name, Drug name, strength and dosage form, Quantity, Sig, Prescriber name, Name of the person who called in prescription (if not the prescriber)
    • Additional requirements for RECEIVING a transferred prescription include:
      • Name and address of the pharmacy which the prescription is transferred from
      • Full name of the pharmacist giving you the information
      • Date of the transfer request
      • Date prescription was written
      • Date of original filling
      • Date of last filling
      • Original refills allowed and number of refills remaining
      • Original Rx number
      • The word Transfer must be written on the face of the prescription. If the drug is a CIII, CIV, or CV include the DEA # of prescriber and pharmacy
  • If you are the one GIVING the transfer information, you must record the following:
    • Full name of the pharmacist
    • Pharmacy name and address where you transferred the prescription.
    • Once you have transferred a prescription out of your pharmacy, you must write VOID on the original hard copy and/or in the pharmacy computer system.

 

TRANSFER FROM ANOTHER PHARMACY (Lab Activity)

Your patient wants you to call her pharmacy and transfer her prescriptions to your location.  She has left you her previous pharmacy’s phone number.  Please call the number found in your workstation, identify yourself from Creighton Dispensing Pharmacy, and ask for the prescription transfers.  The pharmacist that you are calling already knows which prescriptions your patient needs transferred.  Transcribe all of the necessary information in your packet.

data.assign_desc:
Your textbook explains the elements of verbal and physical elements important to creating an effective presentation. To help you learn and apply this material, this discussion involves five steps:

STEP 1: Watch the following TED Talk by Amy Cuddy (2012); note the aspects of Cuddy’s delivery that make the speech particularly compelling. Work to incorporate some of these elements into your own delivery style. Make a list of three elements you want to practice in Step 2 of this assignment.

AmyCuddy_2012G-480p-en.mp4

 

Click Here for a Transcript

 

STEP 2: This assignment requires you to make revisions to the outline you submitted in Module 2. Based on feedback provided by your peers and your instructor, you should make changes to the outline. Also, you should convert the outline from a preparation outline to a presentation outline. This assignment asks you to develop extemporaneous speaking skills, only use your presentation outline to verbally deliver your speech in Step 3. Practice several times before recording so that you are comfortable speaking from an outline. When you practice and record, pay special attention to showcasing strong delivery tactics and implementing style; attend to the elements of delivery Cuddy used that you wish to emulate.

 

STEP 3: Record yourself delivering your speech and upload it to Blueline. Your speech should be between 3-5 minutes. If you are having trouble with this time limit you will likely need to revise your outline or work on your delivery.

 

When you are recording your video remember to do the following:

  •       Put the camera on a stable surface.
  •       Stand 1-3 feet back from the camera.
  •       Adjust the camera so that it is comfortably at eye level. This will help you avoid having to look down to the camera.
  •       Prepare notecards of your presentation; do not read off of your screen or a manuscript.
  •       Speak in a well-lit room.
  •       Speak loudly and clearly, practicing projection just as you would in front of an audience.
  •       Consider the background of your video; avoid objects, posters, and people that will distract your viewers.

Technical Considerations:  

  •       Record your video at a resolution no higher than 720p. Videos recorded in 1080p will have difficulty being uploaded.
  •       Keep the length of your within the assignment expectations. Long videos of 14 minutes at high resolution have difficulty being uploaded.
  •       Recording your video in an MP4 file format helps limit file size and will make uploading videos easier.
  •       Some browsers work better than others. We recommend Google Chrome or Firefox. Safari can work with most features without a problem. You should avoid using Microsoft Internet Explorer.

 

STEP 4: View at least two of your group members’ videos and provide feedback on their performance.

 

In your replies, apply the themes for effective delivery from our textbook (Birkholt, 2014) and Cuddy’s (2012) presentation. Answer the following questions in reply to your peers. Use specific examples from the textbook, Cuddy's presentation, and your group members’ presentations to support your response.

  1. How did your group member employ the functions of delivery?
  2. Vocal delivery?
  3. What about physical delivery? How did your group member use appearance, the space around your group member, time, and objects to develop the presentation?
  4. Provide at least one positive suggestion and one constructive suggestion about your group member's delivery.
