data.assign_desc:
The goal for this assignment is to take everything you have learned this semester and apply to a final presentation.

You will write, record, and publish an address for the ‘‘digital age,’’ adhering to the decorum, customs, limitations, and opportunities that the electronic platform affords. Your topic must be relevant, significant, and substantive (though it does not necessarily have to be a ‘‘heavy’’ topic).You will also need to think about how your topic relates to Jesuit values and the Jesuit concept of Eloquentia Perfecta, the good person speaking well. Videos must be appropriate for public dissemination (remember, this is your public ethos at stake).

Here are some examples from CNN's iReport:

I Can Help Others...

The Shoe Cobbler

A Sandy Story

The It Get Better Project prompted hundreds of videos encouraging hope in others. 

This I Believe also has examples of podcasts that engaged NPR's listeners in a discussion of the core beliefs that guide their daily lives

You may want to search CNN’s iReport Assignments page or Awards page for additional ideas. CNN also explains effective ways to construct your message. Keep in mind that while you may go to these websites for ideas, your own speech should be original. 

This assignment has 4 steps.

STEP 1: Listen to the podcast on Eloquentia Perfecta (listen to a podcast interview). As you listen think about how Eloquentia Perfecta calls us to speak and act on issues of social justice in the contemporary world.

 

STEP 2: Come up with a topic that is relevant, significant, and substantive. Your topic should be, broadly, related to the overall message you have taken away from your Critical Issues in Human Inquiry (CIHI) class. Work to apply a lesson of your CIHI class to the contemporary world so that you can speak about a social issue you care about. Answer the question: What issue in the contemporary world has your CIHI class prepared you to speak about? Consider how your topic relates to the Jesuit Charisms and how as a speaker, you can apply the principles of Eloquentia Perfecta through your message. Research your topic and develop some understanding of its role in the larger world. It may be helpful to choose a topic related to your speech in your Critical Issues in Human Inquiry class (note: these are two different assignments and you will need to adapt them to two different purposes).

 

STEP 3: Make a video that expresses your topic, connects the topic clearly to Jesuit values, and demonstrates your understanding of Eloquentia Perfecta. The video must have a central thesis, utilize organization of main points, and include at least two published and credible sources (verbal citation required within the speech and APA citation required in video’s Description). The video must be between two and four minutes long. At least two-thirds of the video must have you physically in-frame, delivering your message.

 

While this is a digital assignment, it is still oratory. Cutting and editing techniques are allowed and encouraged as appropriate/useful if you feel comfortable using them. You are encouraged to make smart cinematic choices, from good lighting/audio to meaningful background/ foreground decisions. Think of these as more ‘‘available means of persuasion,’’ and make your decisions thoughtfully. If you choose to ‘‘sample’’ or ‘‘re-mix’’ clips for the purposes of your video, be sure to cite your sources and respect Copyright law.

You may work in groups and may choose the same topic as other students, while you are working on topic generation. However, each student must submit an individual/original video that is the product of their own work. 

(OPTIONAL) STEP 4: Each year the Department of Communication Studies will give out the Digital Speaking Lab Eloquentia Perfecta Award for the top video created in this module. To submit your video for consideration, upload it to YouTube (make sure it is publicly visible) and then fill out the form located here: (Entry Form).

Assignment adapted from Lind, 2012.

data.assign_desc:
Your second exam will take place at the beginning of your lab period on Aug. 6th.  It will be closed-book/closed-note, and you will need a pencil and non-programmable calculator.

This exam (30 pts = 30 Qs) will have approximately

5 Qs related to:

  • Determination of the Molar Mass of an Unknown Monoprotic Acid

10 Qs related to:

  • Determination of the Ka and pKa of Acetic Acid
  • Titration of a Polyprotic Acid

10 Qs related to:

  • Preparation of a Buffer pt. 1
  • Preparation of a Buffer pt. 2

and an additional 5 Qs split between general lab stuff and a few questions about the Thermodynamics of the Dissolution of Urea experiment (the same type as might appear on a weekly quiz, to make sure you have prepared for it).

Questions will focus on your understanding of the experiments, but are not intended to test memorization of experimental details.  For example, I didn't expect you to be able to list the five compounds we studied in the "Evaporation and Intermolecular Attractions" experiment, but I did expect you to match evaporation data to a list of possible compounds, based on your ability to predict relative strengths of intermolecular forces and your understanding of how that would affect the change in temperature during evaporation.

To prepare, I suggest you

  • review the experiments we've done, make sure you understand what we did and why, and can analyze similar data
    • Many/most of the titration curve questions will be based on asking you to analyze a curve such as that shown in Figure 1. of the polyprotic titration experiment.  Make sure you can identify pKas, species, equivalence volumes, etc.
  • review previous quizzes - as well as the "possible" questions that didn't make it on to a quiz.  At a minimum, that will help you understand how I ask questions and what I have previously identified as being important.
  • review the experiment links above, re-reading the "By the end of lab, you should..." to remind yourself of the skills identified as important.

data.assign_desc:
Policy on Student Compliance with Technical Standards

The Doctor of Physical Therapy education program in the School of Pharmacy and Health Professions at Creighton University prepares physical therapists to serve as primary providers of physical therapy care. In order to function as a clinical physical therapist, an individual must be able to meet certain physical, emotional, intellectual and communication expectations for performance. Physical therapy education requires the accumulation of scientific knowledge as well as the simultaneous acquisition and demonstration of psychomotor skills and professional attitudes and behaviors. The faculty is committed to an educational environment where students may “identify, define and grow to fulfill the responsibilities of a professional within society”

Program Philosophy

The purpose of technical standards is to delineate the psychomotor, cognitive and affective skills and abilities deemed essential for matriculation into, continuation in and completion of the educational program. Technical standards are necessary to create specific expectations for student performance in the classroom, laboratory and clinical education environments. Technical standards must be met with or without reasonable accommodations consistent with the Americans with Disabilities Act.

Technical Standards - Psychomotor Skills/Observation

The student must possess sufficient sensory and motor function to independently perform a physical therapy examination and intervention utilizing procedures including observation, palpation, auscultation, percussion, bariatric assessment, manual assistance and manual resistance. In general, this requires functional use of vision, hearing and somatic sensation including the ability to perceive position, pressure, movement, weight and vibration. Examples of specific observation skills include examination of non-verbal patient communication, skin integrity, radiographic findings, graphic representations of data, changes in body position/movement and gauges on equipment. A student must be able to respond to occurrences such as a patient calling from behind a curtain, warning calls from anyone and machine alarms. In the classroom, a student must be able to independently observe and participate in laboratory dissection of cadavers, the microscopic analysis of tissues, and lecture and laboratory demonstrations in all courses.

A student must be able to perform motor movements required to provide general and emergency care to all patients. These skills necessitate coordination of gross and fine movement of the trunk and limbs, equilibrium, strength and the integrated use of touch and vision/ hearing. Examples of specific motor abilities include writing or use of a keyboard, performance of gait training using therapeutic aids and orthoses, manual mobilization techniques, non-surgical wound debridement, cardiopulmonary resuscitation and lifting/ moving a patient on a bed/mat or during an assisted transfer between surfaces. A student must be able to possess a level of physical endurance to function under physically challenging workloads or in stressful environments.

Communication

A student must be able to understand and communicate in English effectively with patients and their families. A student must be able to understand and communicate in both written and spoken forms and demonstrate the ability to use therapeutic communication to attend, clarify, coach, facilitate and touch during the patient-provider encounter.

Conceptual/ Integrative Abilities

To effectively solve problems, a student must be able to measure, calculate, reason, analyze, integrate and synthesize information in a timely manner. For example, a student must be able to synthesize knowledge and integrate relevant aspects of the patient history and examination findings in order to develop an accurate physical therapy diagnosis and determine the appropriate intervention within reasonable time constraints imposed by the needs of the patient, the facility and the standards of care.

Behavior, Social Skills and Professionalism

Empathy, integrity, honesty, concern for others, good interpersonal skills, interest and motivation are all required personal qualities. A student must possess the emotional health necessary for the full use of their intellectual abilities, the exercise of good judgement (including the maintenance of patient confidentiality), prompt completion of all responsibilities attendant to course assignments and the development of mature, sensitive and effective patient relationships. This requires the ability of the student to be aware of and appropriately react to one’s own immediate emotional responses. A student is expected to be able to accept and reflect upon appropriate suggestions and criticisms and, if necessary, respond by modifying personal behaviors. Students should also conduct themselves at all times in a manner consistent with the American Physical Therapy Association Code of Ethics and Guide for Professional Conduct.

Attainment of Technical Standards

All students should review the Policy on Student Compliance with Technical Standards and sign below with your NetID acknowledging that the policy has been read and the student attests they are in compliance with the policy. If the student believes that he/she has a disability that necessitates accommodation to meet these technical standards, the student must submit documentation of the disability, along with a request for reasonable accommodation, to the Director of Admission and the Associate Dean for Academic Affairs.

The technical standards are integrated into syllabi in all courses across the curriculum. In certain cases, compliance with technical standards is a prerequisite for a course. In some cases, compliance with technical standards must be maintained to successfully complete a course. Students who fail to meet technical standards that are defined as prerequisite course requirements should request a leave of absence from the program. If a student fails to meet technical standards while participating in a course, the student should discuss the situation with the Instructor of Record(s) and their faculty advisor. Students who cannot meet technical standards while participating in a course may request a grade of Incomplete from the Instructor of Record or request a leave of absence from the program. Otherwise, inability to meet technical standards may result in course failure. If a student believes he/she has a disability that necessitates accommodation to meet these technical standards, the student must submit documentation of the disability, along with a request for a reasonable accommodation, to the Director of Admissions and the Assistant/Associate Dean for Academic Affairs.

data.assign_desc:
1.  All options were true except:  The lymphoid system is very important for the production and distribution of all blood cells.  It is only important for the production and distribution of lymphocytes (not red blood cells or other white blood cells)

2.  The thymus does not remain an essential lymphoid organ through life. It begins to degenerate (involute) during puberty and gets replaced with fat and connective tissue over time.

3.  All options were true except: Lymphatic vessels are under low pressure therefore they do not have valves.  The are a low pressure system and that is why they do in fact have valves.

4.  The thoracic duct is a large lymphatic vessel that drains much of the body's lymph into the left subclavian vein.

5.  Order of structures in respiratory system: nasal cavity, nasopharynx, oropharynx, larynx, trachea, bronchi, bronchioles

6.  The epiglottis does not prevent gastroesophageal reflux.  It prevents food from passing into your larynx.

7.  Sympathetic stimulation causes relaxation of the smooth muscle cells in your bronchi and bronchioles (so you can run away from the dinosaur).

8.  PSCCE lines much but not all of the respiratory system.  It does not line the respiratory portion where gas exchange occurs (blood air barrier).

9.  There are 3 lobes in the right lung and 2 lobes in the left lung.

10.  The four layers that make up the blood air barrier:

surfactant, type I pneumocyte, fused basal lamina, capillary endothelial cell.  You will see this question on the final.

data.assign_desc: Since the first person ever asked you what you were planning on studying in college, you’ve replied, “Bio, Pre-Med.” This has become part of your identity, even if you claim that your plans are subject to change. Honestly, you haven’t really considered any other options. Further, you’ve earned A’s and B’s in your science classes, so there’s still a chance that you will be competitive for medical school. Now, in the middle of your sophomore year, you realize you love your medical sociology class. You find yourself looking forward to your readings in sociology, and doing your organic chemistry homework feels like a chore. You convince yourself that this is only because you have not yet entered the upper-level science classes, where the class size will be smaller and there will be more opportunity to interact with your professors. Additionally, every time you’re home for a break, your parents proudly announce to their friends and members of your extended family that you’ve made the Dean’s List as a pre-med student at Creighton. But when fall registration comes around, you’re not entirely confident in what you want to do. Should you continue in your science classes or try sociology? You don’t have many credit hours to spare, so you feel like wasting credit hours really isn’t an option.

data.assign_desc:
The Office of Academic and Student Affairs welcomes you to Creighton University.

Welcome to the School of Pharmacy and Health Professions!

Hello!  We would like to welcome you to Creighton!  Above you will see photos of the deans in the Office of Academic and Student Affairs; Dr. Paul Price is on the left and Dr. Amy Wilson is on the right.  They serve as the Associate Dean for Academic and Student Affairs and Assistant Dean for Academic Affairs. Below, you will be reviewing and learning more about the policies and procedures of our school.  Review the policies below and sign the acknowledgement at the bottom of this page.

The School of Pharmacy and Health Professions regularly revises existing policies and implements new ones. Complete copies of all School policies are available on the School’s Office of Academic and Student Affairs website. This section of the website summarizes important School policies that directly impact or apply to students. Students are strongly encouraged to review the Creighton University Student Handbook to familiarize themselves with all University policies and School procedures. 

Once you have read this information, click "Take Quiz" at the bottom of this page.

Student Responsibility  
Each SPAHP student is personally responsible for completing all requirements established for his or her degree by the University, the School, and/or department in a timely fashion.  It is the students responsibility to inform him/herself of School policies, procedures and other requirements and to communicate proactively with instructors, administrators or staff in circumstances that may disrupt their ability to advance in their program of studies.  

Disability Accomodation
The School of Pharmacy and Health Professions is committed to support all students’ pursuit of academic goals without discrimination on the basis of gender, race, age, creed, national origin, marital status, or disabling condition.  To achieve equal access to the educational experience, some reasonable accommodations may be necessary to ensure adequate preparation of students for professional practice. This policy assists students with disabilities achieve equal access to the educational experiences available to all students. 

Professional Behavior
The School of Pharmacy and Health Professions recognizes true professionalism as the integration of knowledge and skill with altruistic attitudes, values and behaviors.  In keeping with this philosophy, the policy guides students towards acceptable behaviors, and the corrective action needed in the event of repeated or serious infractions of expected professional conduct.

Professional Behavior Examples
This is an accompanying document to the Professional Behavior Policy.  It describes professional behaviors expected students to develop throughout their academic programs in regards to professional identity, communication skills, critical thinking and critical judgment, and lifelong learning, among others.

Leave of Absence
A Leave of Absence is a planned interruption in a student's formal education program. It is normally short term (one or two semesters) and designed for full-time students in good academic standing (cumulative GPA of 2.0 or above). The principal advantage of a Leave of Absence is that it offers a student the opportunity to leave school temporarily with the assurance that studies can be resumed with minimal difficulty.  The policy describes procedures to initiate a leave of absence.

Scholastic Standing
This policy describes academic performance standards and conditions under which students may accrue academic probationary events while enrolled in didactic or experiential components of School programs. In addition, this policy explains procedures to be followed upon earning an academic probation and/or when a student be dismissed from the School due to unsatisfactory performance.

data.assign_desc:
Teaming Worksheet – #TheRealCreighton Project

 

Discuss the following questions with your teammate and then answer each question on Blueline. Only one member of your team needs to

 

    1. What have your experiences been with group work? What was your best experience? What was your worst? What roles do you tend to adopt in groups?

 

    1. What are your strengths as a team/group member? What are your weaknesses? Be honest with your group members. Are you a procrastinator? Do you easily become annoyed when others don’t respond to your emails and phone calls? Are you occasionally forgetful?

 

    1. What are your skills? Do you have experience with sound and video editing? Do you consider yourself an effective writer? What kinds of assignments have you written well in the past?

 

    1. How will you divide the work evenly for this project? In other words, what will be your general method for deciding who does what?

 

    1. Exchange contact information if you have not already done so. What is the best way for you to contact each other? What are acceptable times to contact each other? How long will it take you to respond to each other under normal (e.g. non-emergency) circumstances?

 

    1. 10% of the points for this project come from peer evaluation. How will you evaluate each other as teammates? (Again, be specific.)

Quiz 6 will cover

Material from the Determination of Ka lab.  At least one question will be derived from the following:

1)  As mentioned in the introduction, the Ka of a substance is the equilibrium constant for the dissociation of a weak acid in water.  What is the equilibrium expression for the dissociation of acetic acid in water?

2) Why do we not need to know the precise concentration of NaOH we use in this experiment?

3) As discussed in lab, the pKa of an acid is equal to the pH when the concentrations of a weak acid [HA] and its conjugate, (weak) base [A-] are the same.  Starting with what you know about the equivalence point, and without using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation, explain how we know that this ([HA]=[A-]) occurs when 1/2 the volume of NaOH necessary to reach the equivalence point has been added.

data.assign_desc:
Answer each of the following 5 questions in complete sentences. Avoid trying to bullet or diagram as the changes in formatting when you save the answer will change the way it looks on the page. Your answer for each question should be under 300 words. Each question is worth 20 points.

1. Define the terms health, communication, and media. Explain why you have chosen to include specific words in your definitions as essential concepts for understanding the meaning of the terms being defined. Finally, in what ways are these terms related?

2. Based on the reading, The Spirit Catches You and You Fall Down: A Hmong Child, Her American Doctors, and the Collision of Two Cultures, explain the roles of culture and language for people who seek and/or receive health care. Additionally, explain the role of culture and language for those who are providing health care.

3. Explain the stress-buffering hypothesis and its importance to health and wellness. Identify four types of stress or stressful events that require different forms of social support and explain why that form of social support is helpful in the case of that particular stress.

4. Explain your beliefs concerning whether or not Direct-To-Consumer Advertising (DTC) should be allowed as it currently is, be more heavily regulated, or be banned. You need to offer reasons and supporting evidence for your position. If you include direct quotations or paraphrased statements in your answer, make sure you cite the source for each instance. Including the authors name (or article title if there is no author indicated) and year of publication is sufficient for this exam. You do not need to include complete citations or a reference list.

5. Based on what you learned in COM 101 about the components of an argument, inaccurate use of facts, and logical fallacies, which two arguments presented in the film Fed Up were the weakest or least persuasive and why? What were the two most persuasive or strongest arguments presented and why? In what ways did the film influence your attitudes or beliefs concerning obesity?

1. True, surface anatomy is the knowledge of anatomical structures and landmarks that can be identified by visual inspection.

2. A, the mental protruberance is the anterior tip of the chin.

3. D, the glenoid fossa is not a surface landmark (all the others were).

4. D, the radial pulse is palpated using the 2nd and or 3rd digit of the opposite hand (located on the anterior surface of the distal radius).

5. True, blood is commonly withdrawn from the median cubital vein.

6.  C, auscultation is listening to the internal sounds of the body.

7.  B, the dorsalis pedis artery can be a useful site to measure the foot pulse (it is located on the dorsum/anterior surface of the foot).

8.  D, the CNS consists of the brain and spinal cord.

9.  False, neurons are not specialized to generate and conduct contractions (electrical impulses, not contractions).

10.  C, the soma is the location of the cell nucleus and protein synthesis organelles.

data.assign_desc:
Patient counseling standards originally were set in the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 (OBRA 1990), which is a law mandating that pharmacists offer counseling to patients regarding their prescriptions.  If the patient accepts this offer, pharmacists should discuss the following:

  • Name of medication
  • Intended use and expected action
  • Route, dosage form, dosage, and administration schedule
  • Proper storage
  • Common adverse effects that may be encountered
  • Techniques for self-monitoring of drug therapy
  • Prescription refill information
  • Action to take if a dose is missed
  • Potential drug–drug or drug–food interactions or other therapeutic contraindications

Although the law was intended for Medicaid patients, individual states adopted rules to make counseling applicable to other patients, as well. Thus, counseling is one of the tools that may be used to provide MTM services. One of the limitations of counseling, however, is that information generally is provided in a one-way, provider-centered manner (i.e., pharmacist to patient or pharmacist to caregiver). Instead, the pharmacist should ask questions to elicit needed information from the patient to fill the medication(s) in question and also to ensure that all of the patient's medications are providing optimal benefit.

Before your counseling session, please review Patient Counseling information under the Resources Module.  This includes the Patient Counseling Checklist, the Patient Counseling Videos, and the Patient Counseling PowerPoint in BlueCast, so you know what to expect.

 

List of Medications:

Medication           Electronic Prescription
Levofloxacin Levofloxacin Electronic Prescription
Augmentin Augmentin Electronic Prescription
Metoclopramide Metoclopramide Electronic Prescription
Lamisil Lamisil Electronic Prescription

data.assign_desc:
As students in technology-rich programs, adequate connectivity is not only a requirement, but a necessity for academic success. The Internet Service Provider (ISP) landscape is ever-changing with the increase use of Internet by virtually all electronic devices – even refrigerators. ISPs in certain areas of the US have started to cap/limit the amount of downloaded data per month and others have started giving preferential service/bandwidth to paid subscriptions, such as Netflix. Since no two providers are the same, students need to check with their provider to assess their current connectivity and address any issue 

OLAT is seeing an ever-increasing number of students who only have cell phones with data plans as well as students who do not have cable TV, but use Internet services such as Netflix, Apple TV, Hulu, Roku, etc. for television viewing, while some students live in rural areas where satellite is still the only provider. All of these devices and technologies are using the bandwidth in your home, even with DSL. 

The SPAHP technology requirements for ALL students of 3.0 Mbps download and upload speed reflects the requirements specified by the various academic technologies used by the University and School. All SPAHP academic technologies are web-based, meaning they are accessible from any Internet or Wi-Fi enabled device. 

  1. To test connectivity level at your home or exam location go to http://speedtest.net.   Distance students, please do this from your location you will be taking exams; Campus students please do this when you move to your home/apartment/dorm in Omaha.
  2. Click "Begin Test"; SpeedTest will automatically choose the closest location to you.
  3. Record the Download and Upload numbers- you will need these to answer the questions! 

here is an example of what you may see:

Once you have read this information and performed the speedtest, click "Take Quiz" at the bottom of this page.  

If you have specific questions about your connectivity or meeting the 3.0 Mb requirement, please contact your internet service provider to adjust your plan.  For more specific information on computer technical requirements, please visit the OLAT site

ESSAY 2

 

THE ESSAY TOPIC WILL BE PROVIDED BY THE INSTRUCTOR

 

WRITE YOUR ESSAY IN YOUR OWN WORD PROCESSING PROGRAM AND THEN PASTE IT INTO THE TEXT ENTRY AREA PROVIDED HERE. MAKE SURE TO KEEP A COPY OF YOUR WORK.

 

DO NOT TRY TO TYPE THE ESSAY DIRECTLY INTO THE TEXT ENTRY AREA AS COMPUTERS ARE TREACHEROUS AND A GLITCH COULD CAUSE YOU TO LOSE ALL YOUR WORK JUST AS YOU WERE TYPING YOUR LAST WORD.

Length: 750 - 1250 words (it's perfectly fine if you feel inspired and want to write more -- just make sure your words are well used providing substantial analysis, explanations and evidence)

 

While you are free to determine the specific thesis of your essay, it is most important that it be YOUR OWN WORK and that it demonstrates YOUR GRASP AND UNDERSTANDING of the materials and ideas studied in the course.

 

Pay very close attention to details, offer evidence and full explanations for all your claims in the form of precise observations and analysis of details and textual evidence. Remember that ANY SOURCES CONSULTED HAVE TO BE CLEARLY CITED AND ACKNOWLEDGED

 

See Writing Guidelines for details on citing sources and matters of style. Use your own words. Write clearly, Get to the point. Provide evidence and argument to support your ideas.

Please call the phone number in your work station and get 8 transfer prescriptions for your patient.

The information required for a pharmacy prescription transfer is as follows:

    • All basic information from the original prescription
      • Patient name, Drug name, strength and dosage form, Quantity, Sig, Prescriber name, Name of the person who called in prescription (if not the prescriber)
    • Additional requirements for RECEIVING a transferred prescription include:
      • Name and address of the pharmacy which the prescription is transferred from
      • Full name of the pharmacist giving you the information
      • Date of the transfer request
      • Date prescription was written
      • Date of original filling
      • Date of last filling
      • Original refills allowed and number of refills remaining
      • Original Rx number
      • The word Transfer must be written on the face of the prescription. If the drug is a CIII, CIV, or CV include the DEA # of prescriber and pharmacy
  • If you are the one GIVING the transfer information, you must record the following:
    • Full name of the pharmacist
    • Pharmacy name and address where you transferred the prescription.
    • Once you have transferred a prescription out of your pharmacy, you must write VOID on the original hard copy and/or in the pharmacy computer system.

 

TRANSFER FROM ANOTHER PHARMACY (Lab Activity)

Your patient wants you to call his pharmacy and transfer his prescriptions to your location.  He has left you his previous pharmacy’s phone number.  Please call the number found in your workstation, identify yourself from Creighton Dispensing Pharmacy, and ask for the prescription transfers.  The pharmacist that you are calling already knows which prescriptions your patient needs transferred.  Transcribe all of the necessary information in your packet.

A common error in titrating is to "overtitrate,", and add more NaOH than necessary to reach the equivalence point.  How would overtitrating on the standardization of KHP ultimately affect your calculated molar mass (assuming you used the value in your calculations)?  On your actual titration?  Be able to explain your reasoning.

data.assign_desc:
NOTE: you must complete LEO first for this module.

Now that you have completed your Library Encounter Online exercise, for your discussion post, you will (a) find sources of information and (b) apply this information that relate to the following statement: “Humans are causing global climate change.”

Find one source using library resources that would support or refute the statement above. Next, determine how credible you believe this source to be. The way to answer this question is to determine how your source meets EACH of the following criteria:

  • Is the author (or authors) of the information identified or is it anonymous?
  • Is the author (or authors) credible?
  • Is it a primary or secondary source?
  • Is the source recent enough for your purpose?
  • Is the information relevant to the statement?
  • Is the information consistent with other sources?
  • Following APA (6th edition) guidelines create a citation based on the source you found for a reference page.  Please see your textbook and Purdue OWL for additional information on how to cite using APA format.

After you post your evaluation of your source and citation, look at all of the sources posted within your discussion group. Reply to two of your group members. Your replies should consist of having a discussion with your group to determine which source is the most credible and which is the least out of all of the sources your group found.

data.assign_desc:
Using direct text entry, and on the basis of the reading, write three critical questions complete with answers, and five new vocabulary words complete with definitions. The vocabulary words can be technical terms from the reading or simply regular words whose definition you do not already know. These assignments are worth five points each and will be accepted only in text-entry format.

Here are a couple of example questions:

   Q. Who was Eusebius of Caesarea and why is he important?

   A. Eusebius of Caesarea was a fourth-century church historian who served the Emperor Constantine and recorded traditions about Christian persons, places, and events known in his time.

   Q. How did Augustine of Hippo respond to the barbarian invasion and sack of Rome in 410? 

   A. Augustine responded to the barbarian invasion and sack of Rome by writing The City of God, in which he argued that the earthly city in the present age was a place of trial and tribulation, and that the Christian's true citizenship was in the heavenly city of God.

 

Here are a few examples of terms and their definitions:

   Vulgate: A Latin translation of the Bible produced by Jerome in the late fourth century, which he based on Hebrew and Greek manuscripts.

   Promulgated: Made official, put into law.

   Theotokos: Literally, Bearer (or Mother) of God, a title applied to Mary, which affirms the virgin birth of the divine Son of God.

data.assign_desc:
New occupational therapy students are required to be a student member of the American Occupational Therapy Association (AOTA). Follow instructions closely below.

New occupational therapy students are required to be a student member of the American Occupational Therapy Association (AOTA). The reasons and benefits for becoming a student member in your professional organization are many. First, as a developing professional you have the opportunity to receive and access a number of resources.

For the Fall 2016 semester, you will need to access resources provided on the AOTA Member Website during the first week of class. For example, in the course OTD 316, Professional Practice and Ethical Formation, by being able to access some AOTA online materials online, you are able to avoid purchasing several textbooks this semester.

It takes several weeks after you complete the membership form to receive your username and password. In order to have this by the time class starts, you will need to complete the form by the July 18 deadline. The special student membership fee of $75 (graduates pay $225) automatically comes from student fees you pay as part of your first fall semester tuition and fees schedule. You do NOT need to send money, but only complete the form as directed below:

In order to acquire an AOTA membership, please complete the steps below by MONDAY, JULY 18, 2016.

  • Click below to access the required forms. The forms are in .pdf format and will require Acrobat Reader.
    • AOTA Membership Application
    • Print both pages (front and back) of the AOTA Membership Application.
    • Complete both pages of the AOTA Membership Application. 
    • Under "Special Interest Sections" on Page 2, you may indicate any SIS Codes.
    • Please leave the payment information blank, as Creighton will complete that information for you.
  • By Monday, July 18, 2016, at 12:00 noon Central, please submit your completed application to Jackie Lawrence in the Department of Occupational Therapy using one of these methods:
    • Scan and email to jlawrence@creighton.edu 
    • Fax to 402.280.5692.
    • Please do NOT mail the completed application.
  • Your application will be submitted to AOTA by the Department of Occupational Therapy, so please do not submit it to AOTA yourself.

If you have any questions regarding the application, please contact Jackie Lawrence at 402.280.1864 or jlawrence@creighton.edu 

Once you have read this information and completed the submission of your form, click "Take Quiz" at the bottom of this page.

data.assign_desc:
Through this course, you will be learning communication strategies unique to the healthcare environment. To enhance your understanding of the roles of other healthcare professionals and to allow you to practice your communication strategies, you are required to interview another healthcare professional using the provided questions. Prior to and after conducting your interview, you will complete a survey evaluating your knowledge and ability to communicate with another healthcare professional.

Instructions:

 

  1. Pre-survey will be completed on the first day of class for campus students and by Saturday, August 27, 2016 at 5 p.m. for distance students
  2. Identify a healthcare professional to interview from the list of acceptable options
  3. Select a date and time to conduct your interview
  4. Interview must answer at least one question from each category (roles/responsibilities, interprofessional communication, teams and teamwork, and values/ethics) PLUS must answer all asterisked questions
    1. Interview questions
  5. Submit typed interview on BlueLine by Wednesday, November 30th at 11:55 p.m.
  6. Typed interview must include:
    1. Your name at the top of the assignment
    2. Date the interview was conducted
    3. Name of the healthcare professional interviewed and their profession
    4. Questions you asked the interviewee
    5. Answers written in complete sentences with proper grammar
  7. Complete post-survey following the interview
  8. Late submissions will not be accepted

data.assign_desc:
This semester’s BIO 205 Writing Assignment Theme is “Perception and Communication”.  All organisms must have mechanisms by which they perceive the environment around them.  Organisms, particularly relatively sessile organisms like plants, fungi, bacteria, and some invertebrates,  have mechanisms to perceive environmental stimuli, such as temperature, light,  gravity, and water and nutrient availability. Organisms must also perceive biotic factors, such as the presence of mates, competitors, predators, and prey items. Perception of both abiotic and biotic factors may involve sight, sound, touch, taste, chemicals, electrical signals, light or other mechanisms. Similarly, organisms have mechanisms by which they can communicate information to other members of the same species or members of other species. This might include communication with potential mates, competitors, symbiotes, predators, or prey. Communication might be audio, visual, chemical, or through some other means.

For your paper, you will research an aspect of perception or communication in an organism or organisms within your assigned taxonomic group. You might want to focus on a particular species or type of organisms, such as mechanisms of perception in sharks or communication with fungal symbiotes in plants. Alternatively, you might want to compare and contrast perception in two different types of organisms within your group, such as communication between mates in two types of spiders or birds. You might also explore a particular kind of perception or communication mechanism, such as vocalization in insects or quorum sensing in bacteria. Remember that this is a biology class, so the majority of your paper should focus on biological concepts.

General Instructions: Please see page 141-145 of your lab manual for all guidelines.

  • Your assignment is to write an essay of about 1500 words (approximately 5 double-spaced pages). The word count must be included at the end of the paper. The essay must be submitted in electronic format to the appropriate online folder.  Your TA will provide you with more specifics about the submission process. Your essay is due by 11:59 pm on November 21st. It is your responsibility to retain an electronic copy of the essay in case of technical difficulties. Note that for late submissions, a 10% grade reduction will be applied for every 24 hours past the submission deadline.
  • You are to use scientific essay format in writing your paper.  A variety of slightly different specific styles are acceptable, but there are some common features to the scientific essay format, which are discussed below.  In general, a good way to proceed is to follow the style used in a science book from Reinert Alumni Library. You should always feel free to ask your instructors or TA any questions you have about the essay's format, but the following paragraphs should anticipate most questions you might have, so read them carefully prior to writing your essay.
  • In your essay, you are required to cite at least five sources, and to list your sources in a bibliography as described in the previous exercise.  At least three of the five must be from the primary scientific literature (sources written by the scientists who actually performed the studies). The other two may be secondary sources (work described by individuals other than the scientists who did the studies), including review articles. Both primary scientific literature and review articles are considered scholarly, scientific sources and should make up the bulk of your sources. You should use Internet web sites or clearly non-scientific sources on a limited basis and use extreme care when choosing these sources; the Library BIO 205 course guide provides a list of acceptable internet resources.  Note that printed journal articles that are also accessible on the web count as “scholarly, scientific sources”.  You are encouraged and expected to consider the relevance of additional material encountered since the submission of the bibliography and, thus, your bibliography might not be identical to the bibliography you previously submitted.
  • Failure to cite articles appropriately may be considered plagiarism and result in the appropriate penalties.

data.assign_desc:
PROJECT PROPOSAL. All projects must be approved by the instructor in advance. Project Proposals will be brief statements (about one paragraph to one page maximum) describing the topic, medium, materials. and ideas to be explored in the project.

 

Each student will design and complete a term project based on or inspired by any aspect of the themes,
ideas, characters, situations, symbols, or other features of the texts studied in the course. Students are
encouraged to be creative and imaginative and to choose material and media which are interesting and
stimulating. Not all projects involve written work but brief written reflections may accompany creative
projects to clarify their nature and significance. Students choosing to write a paper must follow the
instructor's "Guidelines for Papers." For further information on the writing and grading of papers see
Grading Standards and Procedures, and Grading of Essays and Other Written Work.


All projects must be personal, original, relevant, and specifically designed and produced for this course.
Recycling projects from other classes or attempting to use work authored by others or not produced
specifically for this course will be considered forms of cheating and academic dishonesty. (see policy
below).

Projects may be undertaken in any of the following formats or media:

  • ANALYTICAL AND/OR RESEARCH PAPERS (minimum 1000 words)
  • CREATIVE WRITING (FICTION, POETRY OR DRAMA (minimum 1000 words)
  • PAINTING OR DRAWING
  • ORIGINAL MUSICAL COMPOSITION AND/OR PERFORMANCE
  • SCULPTURE
  • POSTER COLLAGE
  • FILM OR DOCUMENTARY
  • DANCE CHOREOGRAPHY AND PERFORMANCE
  • THEATER SKITS
  • OTHER PERFORMANCE PIECES
  • WEBSITE
  • OTHER FORMATS OR MEDIA NOT LISTED HERE MAY ALSO BE ACCEPTABLE (ask the
    instructor).

data.assign_desc:
Before engaging in this course, we want to know your perceptions about readiness for participation in interprofessional collaboration. We recognize you may have not experienced health care teamwork at this point - that is okay! We simply want to know what you think about health care teamwork and collaboration. This tool lets us know what you feel before you have learned about teamwork and after you have learned some of the concepts in the course. Answer these statements based on your beliefs about what you believe health care teamwork to be. 

Prior to any modules, you will need to complete the Readiness for Interprofessional Learning Scale. This quiz is a self-assessment of readiness for interprofessional learning. You will also complete this scale after the lessons to assess your knowledge of teams. For each statement, rate your ability to carry out each of the following tasks. Answer openly and honestly. 

a 19-item tool with a 5-point scale that is used to assess the readiness of health care students for interprofessional education. The tool has 3 subscales: teamwork and collaboration, negative and positive professional identity, and roles and responsibilities  (Curran, Sharpe,  Forristall, & Flynn, 2008) - See more at: https://nexusipe.org/informing/resource-center/ripls-readiness-interprofessional-learning-scale

 Curran, V. R., Sharpe, D., Forristall, J., and Flynn, K. (2008). Attitudes of health sciences students towards interprofessional teamwork and education. Learning in Health and Social Care, 7(3), 146­‐156.

data.assign_desc:
As this chapter discussed, messages are more effective when they draw from multiple, and ideally all, forms of persuasive proof (ethos, logos, pathos, and mythos). 

For this discussion, watch the following John Oliver video on the state of prisons in the United States.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_Pz3syET3DY

Whether you agree with Oliver or not, there is no doubt his comedic bit was also intended to be persuasive. In your post, provide one example of each of the four proofs. Display quotes and/or screen shots of Oliver's bit for each. And, explain how you think your examples illustrate each of the four artistic proofs.

In your replies to two group members, have a discussion about which type of artistic proof seems most effective for Oliver's purpose and which type of artistic proof seems least effective.

Before lab, you should...

  • Read all of the experiment writeup.
    • Mark it up with any notes or questions you may have!
  • Recognize that we're using dyes...and that dyes stain - dress accordingly!
  • Write an introduction for this experiment in your lab notebook.  Your introduction should have a sentence or two on Parts B and C (A is just setup), but focus on Part D as the actual experiment.
  • Make sure you
    • Can do basic dilution calculations for Part D.
      • A practice quiz (not required, ungraded) is here.
    • Remember how to use a Mohr pipette.  If you need a refresher, you can view this video:
  • Refer to Sections 5.2 and 20.10 (Figures 20.25 and 20.26, in particular, may help you understand the material) of your textbook, or go to Dr. Gunn's office hours if you need more help with the background information.  If you don't understand Parts B and C right now, that's okay - those parts make more sense once you do them - that's why we do them!

By the end of lab, you should...

  • Understand how the color we perceive and the wavelength of light are related
  • Be able to determine the molar absorptivity of a substance

This lab will provide you with practical skills you will need for the following two experiments - make sure you understand it!

data.assign_desc:
Public speaking is often the first step in argument construction and speakers often encounter opponents who disagree with some or all of their positions. In this assignment you will advance an argument for a policy change (change in law that alters the status quo) you would like the State of Nebraska to adopt. Your peers will then refute your arguments. The following assignment has three steps.

 

STEP 1: Research a change that you believe should be made to current law in the State of Nebraska. Be sure you have enough support for your argument.

 

STEP 2: In your initial post state your argument using all 4 parts of the Stock Issues model described in your textbook (Birkholt, 2014). Support each part with evidence by citing your sources. You must use at least 4 pieces of evidence to build your case, but stronger arguments will likely use more. Be sure to remember the standards for evidence you learned in Module 3.

 

STEP 3: In your replies to two of your group members, practice the 5 steps of refutation you read about in your textbook (Birkholt, 2014). Your goal is to argue against your peer’s initial post. Your refutation will also likely require the use of evidence. Be sure to cite any sources that are helpful to your refutation. Another strategy you may use is to look for argumentative fallacies they have used in building their argument.

data.assign_desc:
Quiz 8 will cover

Material from the Buffers (pt. 1) experiment.

The quiz will have at least one of the following questions (in some form):

1)  Consider the following situation:  when adding acid to your buffer (5 drops at a time), you obtain the following data:

Drops of HCl pH
0 5.50
5 5.41
10 5.31
15 5.20
20 4.84
25 3.59

 

How do you explain the sudden change in pH starting at ~20 drops of HCl?

 

2)  When preparing your buffer, you chose the acid/conjugate base combination with a pKa closest to your target pH.  As a rule of thumb, the pKa of your chosen weak acid must be within 1 pH unit of your target pH to make an effective buffer.  Why is this the case?

(Hint:  to get started, try using the H-H equation to calculate [A-]/[HA] for, say, pH 7, using several theoretical pKas.)

 

Material from the Buffers, pt. 2 experiment:

  • Make sure you can do what is asked of you in the "Before you come to lab" portion
  • Do you know what substances we're using and how to dispose of them?
  • Do you have a basic idea of the main steps we'll be doing in lab and how to do the relevant calculations?

View the textbook information provided below so you can plan for Fall 2016 courses.

Textbooks are a critical part of student learning.  In order to be successful in the classroom, you can view the books that will be required for coursework this fall.  View your Fall Course Schedule by selecting your respective programs' schedule to determine the courses you are taking for Fall 2016.  Distance students, refer to the School Catalog or use the campus pathway schedule as a guide for a list of required courses.

It is recommended that books be purchased through the Creighton Bookstore which contains the official location for all required and optional texts' for courses.  There are two ways to view your course materials.

OPTION 1

  • Go to the Registrar's Schedule of Courses page and click "Fall" in the upper-left area of the page.
  • In the "Subject" box, select your program: OTD Occupational Therapy, PHA Pharmacy, or PTD Physical Therapy.
  • You may click "Class Search" at this point but if you want to be more specific, you can enter a specific course number by viewing your Fall Course Schedule.
  • You will see the Class Schedule Listing based on your search criteria for Fall 2016.  For each course, click on "View Course Materials".  This will provide you the textbook information needed (note that some instructors may not yet have turned in course materials).

OPTION 2 

  • Go to the Creighton Bookstore online store.
  • Mouse over "Books" tab and click on "Textbooks and Course Material".
  • Select your term which is "Fall 2015" 
  • Select your department: "OTD" ('C' for campus, 'AK' for Alaska, 'CO' for Regis, 'NE' for GO) for Occupational Therapy, "PHA" ('C' for campus and 'W' for distance) and "PTD" for Physical Therapy. 
  • Refer to the Fall Course Schedule to select your course number on the bookstore website to view the materials for each course regardless of your pathway.

You have been registered for courses by the Office of Academic and Student Affairs. You do not have to take any action as this is taken care of for you as an incoming student but you can verify your registration by logging into NEST.  Log in using your NetID and blue password, click on "Student Services", then registration, then follow the prompts.

Some courses may not have course materials/books listed.  This is at the discretion of the instructor and more information will be provided when classes begin.

Questions specific to each course can be emailed to the Instructor of Record listed on course schedule.

This quiz consists of 5, 1 point, questions and you will have 8 minutes to complete it. Review the notes for the lectures on Animal Diversity (Oct. 17; Oct. 27, 29, 31) and associate chapters, 33-35.  

You may have this written material available during the quiz, but because of the time limit, you may not have time to refer to it.  Thus, it is a good practice to thoroughly review the lecture notes and associated text book chapters before opening the quiz.  Also, it is good to become accustomed to taking the quiz without referring to notes since this is what you will be asked to do during the exams.  Do not open the quiz until you are ready to take it because the timer starts as soon as you open it.   Blueline does not allow you to suspend work on the quiz and come back to it later. 

You will be allowed two attempts and your grade will represent the best of the attempts.  Note that I have changed this setting from previous quizzes, in which the grade was the latest attempt.  Thus, there is no reason to avoid taking the quiz again if you can improve your score. 

Keep in mind the academic honesty policy and complete this quiz independently without assistance from another person.  You must be logged in under your own student ID in order to have the points go in the grade book accurately. 

Good luck!

data.assign_desc:
Now that you are done with this course, we are interested in your beliefs about teams. Complete the Readiness for Interprofessional Learning Scale. This quiz is a self-assessment of your beliefs about your readiness to participate in an interprofessional team. For each statement, rate your ability to carry out each of the following tasks. Answer openly and honestly. 

Prior to any modules, you will need to complete the Readiness for Interprofessional Learning Scale. This quiz is a self-assessment of readiness for interprofessional learning. You will also complete this scale after the lessons to assess your knowledge of teams. For each statement, rate your ability to carry out each of the following tasks. Answer openly and honestly. 

The RIPLS is a 19-item tool with a 5-point scale that is used to assess the readiness of health care students for interprofessional education. The tool has 3 subscales: teamwork and collaboration, negative and positive professional identity, and roles and responsibilities  (Curran, Sharpe,  Forristall, & Flynn, 2008) - See more at: https://nexusipe.org/informing/resource-center/ripls-readiness-interprofessional-learning-scale

 Curran, V. R., Sharpe, D., Forristall, J., and Flynn, K. (2008). Attitudes of health sciences students towards interprofessional teamwork and education. Learning in Health and Social Care, 7(3), 146­‐156.

data.assign_desc:
The Center for Health and Counseling provides important student health needs.

Creighton University's Center for Health and Counseling (CHC) is located in the Harper Center, suite 1034 and houses both Student Health Services and Student Counseling Services.

Student Health serves students in 3 major roles: Health Care Provider group, Student Health Insurance plan sponsor, and Campus Health Outreach. Student Health is a full-service medical clinic staffed with physicians, nurse practitioners and physician assistants to meet your primary health care needs. On site lab and x-ray is available. We are your Home for Healthcare on Campus.

Click here for a short presentation by Sue Weston, RN. Ms. Weston provides insight on how Student Health works and immunization requirements at Creighton University.

UNIVERSITY HEALTH INSURANCE REQUIREMENT

ALL Full-time Students are required to have comprehensive health insurance. A full description of the health insurance plan can be found on the Creighton Student Health Services website.

Enrollment in the University endorsed health insurance plan is automatic for all full-time students. The annual premium will be applied to the student’s account unless an online waiver is completed (see waiver information below). Detailed information may be obtained by visiting the Student Health Services website (listed above).

Health insurance waivers will start being accepted for enrolled students in July. The insurance waiver process can be completed by logging in to your NEST account and clicking on the "Student Services" link/tab. The waiver process must be completed each academic year. Please complete the waiver process promptly to avoid an unnecessary insurance premium charge. After September 1, 2016, the University will not be able to remove the charge and you will remain enrolled in the insurance plan until August 2017.

Once you have read this information , click "Take Quiz" at the bottom of this page.
data.assign_title: Health Insurance Requirements and Student Health Overview

data.assign_desc:
In addition to the commercial background check through Verified Credentials, Inc., students in the Alaska pathway are required to complete a criminal background check through the state of Alaska, as required by health care facilities in Alaska. Please note that many facilities in Alaska require employees to complete both a state of Alaska background check and a commercial background check. This will be the case for students, as well, since you will have labs and fieldwork experiences at these facilities. Please follow the instructions carefully, as there are many details involved in this process.

The purpose of this requirement is to help ensure the public and patient safety. It will also assure you as a Creighton University student that you meet the minimum background screening requirements for employment prior to devoting your time and money to secure a degree. Healthcare facilities today are becoming very cautious in terms of their hiring practices not only to protect their patients, but also to protect the hospital.  ALL STUDENTS MUST COMPLETE THIS PROCESS.

I have attached the information and forms necessary for this process.  Please note:  The Background Check Unit requires that all documents, fingerprints, and fees be submitted to their office within 30 days of the online application.  If there are any missing documents, fingerprints, or fees, the application will be cancelled.  You will need to reapply and resubmit all fees and documents again and the original fees will not be refunded.   For more details read THIS.

The Process Step 1: DUE TUES AUG 2

Complete the form found HERE and turn in the completed form to the AK Fingerprinting assignment submission folder.  

The Process Step 2: DUE THURS AUG 4

Follow the instructions found HERE.  You will receive a confirmation page which will tell you if fingerprints are required. If so, there will be a link provided that opens a finger print request form.  See an example HERE.  Please print this request form and bring it with you to Welcome Week to get fingerprinted on THURSDAY AUGUST 4.  Also bring with you payment for the fingerprinting (separate from online payment for background check, have cash and check ready). If you encounter problems with your online application, or have questions please call the Alaska State Background Check Unit at 907-334-4475.

data.assign_desc:
In this module, you will play two different roles: (a) Speaker and (b) Critical Listener.

As Speaker, you will do two things:

First, One week (7 Days) before your major CIHI presentation:

  • One week before you give your speech in class, you need to upload a video of the speech you are planning to give in your Critical Issues course.
  • You will upload this video as an initial discussion post.
  • Once you upload your video, send an email to your group members letting them know your speech is ready for feedback. You can email them by clicking the "Inbox" tab in the top right corner, click the "compose a new message" button, select your section of COM 101, click the black profile button, and choose your group members. 
  • Creating and posting your video is worth 7.5 points.

48 Hours before you are to give your presentation in your CIHI course:

  • After you receive feedback from the other people in your group, you must reply to your original video posting with a discussion reflection in changes you have made in your speech based on feedback you have received from your peers.
  • The reflection portion of this assignment is worth 7.5 points.  

As you develop your presentation, keep in mind all of the components we have discussed in COM 101 and apply these principals to your CIHI presentation. Some of the topic areas we covered include using the five Canons of Rhetoric, creating a preparation outline (likely the same outline you will give your CIHI instructor), a presentation outline, using transitions, developing a preview and summary statement, stating your thesis, verbally citing sources, creating a reference page of sources, using energy and enthusiasm, providing meaningful gestures, establishing eye contact with your audience, and using a visual aid that best supplements your presentation. You should consider implementing all of these strategies into your CIHI presentation and any future presentations.  

We encourage you to stand up, use note cards, and dress professionally for this practice presentation.  

 

As Critical Listener, you complete the following for each member of your discussion group.

48 Hours after a group member has posted a presentation:

  • Once you receive notice that one of your group members has uploaded a video, you have 48 hours to reply to their video with feedback.
  • Your discussion reply should include at least two strengths to retain and two areas of improvement.
  • You must provide feedback to each member of your group as they post their practice speech. (Note: This may occur at different times in the last half of the semester, depending on your CIHI speaking schedule.)
  • Providing substantial feedback to all group members is worth 15 points.

Below are some guidelines for your video:

When your recording your video remember to do the following:

  • Put the camera on a stable surface.
  • Stand 1-3 feet back from the camera.
  • Adjust the camera so that it is comfortably at eye level. This will help you avoid having to look down to the camera.
  • Prepare notecards of your presentation; do not read off of your screen or a manuscript.
  • Speak in a well-lit room.
  • Speak loudly and clearly, practicing projection just as you would in front of an audience.
  • Consider the background of your video; avoid objects, posters, and people that will distract your viewers.

 

Technical Considerations:  

  • Record your video at a resolution no higher than 720p. Videos recorded in 1080p will have difficulty being uploaded.
  • Keep the length of your within the assignment expectations. Long videos of 14 minutes at high resolution have difficulty being uploaded.
  • Recording your video in an MP4 file format helps limit file size and will make uploading videos easier.
  • Some browsers work better than others. We recommend Google Chrome or Firefox. Safari can work with most features without a problem. You should avoid using Microsoft Internet Explorer.

data.assign_desc:
A Creighton University ID card is required for all Regis Creighton OT students. Go to the Card Services website and follow the instructions to ensure you have a photo ID before the academic year begins. Please complete the process before Friday, July 8, 2016.  Your Creighton ID will then be issued to you at Welcome Week registration. All students will be required to have their Creighton ID on the first day of Welcome Week, Monday, August 8.

Today's Creighton ID card is more than a visual credential; it is a key to access many of the services available to members of the Creighton Community. The first card issued to you comes at no charge.

Your ID card interfaces with many different systems, granting (or denying) access to services such as door access, email, library materials, meal plans, photocopies and the only item that holds a unique identifier to reset your blue password.

Because of the number of systems requiring your card, it is important to keep it in good condition. Any card returned to our office not functioning due to intentional damage will cost the user $10. Lost or stolen cards may be replaced for a fee of $20. Each time an ID is replaced, the number changes, deactivating the previous card. For security purposes, old cards cannot be reactivated.

http://www.creighton.edu/admin/cardservices/distancelearningstudents/

data.assign_desc:
There are 2 parts to this background check procedure.  SCROLL down for Part 2.

The Creighton University School of Pharmacy and Health Professions requires criminal background checks for all enrolled students in order to verify an individual's suitability to participate in experiential education rotations and to ensure patient safety. The Criminal Background Check process for all students has two parts:

PART 1:
Certiphi Criminal Background Check
Certiphi is the company that completes all criminal background checks for School of Pharmacy and Health Professions Students. It is likely that you have already begun this part of the background check process. If so, congratulations! You are well on your way to completing the process. Certiphi sends us this information and if any discrepancies exist between what you reported and what they uncovered, we will contact you. Information about this process was emailed to you directly from Certiphi shortly after you were accepted to the School of Pharmacy and Health Professions.

PART 2:
Nebraska DHHS Request for Information from the Adult and Child Abuse and Neglect Registry
The state of Nebraska requires by law that all incoming health science students complete this step before officially enrolling in a health science program. This is regardless of whether you currently reside, previously resided, or plan on residing in the state of Nebraska in the future. A form from the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services is available on this page. This form needs to be completed, must be NOTARIZED (despite what is indicated on the form), and sent back to the Office of Admission NO LATER THAN June 15, 2016. Below are a couple of important reminders/suggestions for completing the form:

  • Be sure to accurately TYPE all personal information into the form, and include as much detail as possible. Agency information (Agency ID Number, Agency Name) and information regarding they type of check as been provided for you.
  • Print the form
  • Do not sign the form until you are in the presence of a Notary Public
  • Arrange to sign the form in the presence of a Notary Public and have the form notarized.
  • Please pay close attention to your signature; it must be legible. If it is illegible the agency will ignore the request.
  • Mail the form to:
    SPAHP Office of Admission
    Criss Health Science III, Room 151
    2500 California Plaza
    Omaha, NE 68178 

Once you have read this information and mailed your form, click "Take Quiz" at the bottom of this page.

data.assign_desc:
Before lab, you should

  • Make sure you have all your lab supplies!  (Safety glasses, lab notebook, and lab manual.  These can be purchased from the Chemistry stockroom.  See my e-mails for days, times and cost)
  • Be dressed appropriately - long pants and closed-toe shoes are required (bringing a pair of sweatpants to pull on over your shorts is both acceptable and common!)
  • Read the entire experiment (including all parts of the Introduction and Procedure).
    • Mark up your lab manual with any notes or questions you may have!
    • You will NOT need to write an introduction (or anything else) before you come - we'll discuss that in lab.

By the end of lab, you should...

  • Be familiar with the rules for significant figures.  This includes
    • Determining how many significant figures a number has.
    • Determining how many significant figures will be in the answer to a multiplication or division question.
    • Determining how many significant figures will be in the answer to an addition or subtraction question.
    • Determining how many significant figures will be in the answer to a multi-step calculation involving both addition/subtraction and multiplication/division.

     

    • Be able to quickly find all laboratory safety equipment and exits

     

  • Be able to accurately identify and use top-loader balances, graduated cylinders, and other measuring tools.
  • Be familiar with the difference between accuracy and precision.
  • Be able to accurately determine the density of solids, including irregularly shaped solids.

As you read the article for discussion in class, use the following questions to help guide your reading. Answer each question as part of your preparation. Copy and paste the following questions into your reply.

1. What research questions are the authors attempting to answer?

2. What theory are they using to guide their research? Identify the theory and briefly explain the main components of the theory.

3. Is this research quantitative or qualitative?

4. Describe the participants or research subjects for this article.

5. What instruments were used to collect data?

6. What was the form of the data collected?

7. What methods were employed to analyze the data?

8. What were the results of the analysis?

9. What conclusions did the authors draw based on this research?

10. What are the limitations of this research?

11. What practical utility do you see for this research?

Before lab, you should...

  • Read the lab manual
    • Mark it up with any notes or questions you may have!
  • Write an introduction for this experiment in your lab notebook.
  • Make sure you understand how to estimate pKa1 and pKa2 from a titration curve for the titration of a weak acid with strong base.
    • pKa1 is found the same way as in the Determination of Ka lab.
    • pKa2 requires that you take the difference in volumes between equivalence point 1 or 2.  (Think of it as "starting over" at the first equivalence volume.)
  • Refer to Sections 14.11 and 15.9 of your textbook, or go to Dr. Gunn's office hours if you need more help with the background information.

By the end of lab, you should...

  • Be comfortable interpreting the titration curve for a polyprotic acid.
  • Be able to correctly identify regions of a polyprotic acid-base titration curve
  • Be able to accurately determine the pKa values for a polyprotic acid.

data.assign_desc:
Please read this ENTIRE MESSAGE carefully as it pertains to Pharmacist Intern Credentialing in Nebraska, a requirement FOR our program.

The purpose of this email is to inform you of the requirements for preparing your application for credentialing you as an intern pharmacist in Nebraska. Please review the attached application letter and form at this time for INFORMATIONAL PURPOSES ONLY. 

DO NOT COMPLETE THIS FORM NOW! We will process it together at the MANDATORY meeting on Wednesday, August 17th during Welcome week!

A partially completed form will be provided to each of you for that meeting. You will complete THAT application FORM AND RETURN IT TO US AT THAT TIME! we will send all applications into the state.

IMPORTANT INFORMATION:

This application is a legal document.

NE DHHS (Department of Health and Human Services) will do a background check on you. If the DHHS finds a discrepancy in regard to your application, you may be denied the credential.

On August 17th, you must bring copies of documentation that shows proof of age AND proof of citizenship and/or lawful presence (read top half of page 2 of applicant letter): Bring a COPY of each of your original documents (e.g., birth certificate and marriage certificate, driver’s license etc.) – since originals will NOT be returned to you.

In most cases a birth certificate OR a US passport is sufficient (an expired passport will work) to prove citizenship and age. A copy of your driver’s license only shows your proof of age; you will have to provide another document showing proof of citizenship.

If your last name is different from the one on your birth certificate (e.g., changed due to marriage or divorce), you must provide documentation of that name change (i.e., marriage certificate).

There is a $50 application fee which will be paid by Creighton University SPAHP – do NOT write a check or purchase a money order for this fee.

Pay special attention to paragraphs 3 and 4 of the applicant letter in order to answer the questions on page 2 of the application. (“Yes” answers will require you to supply further information. It is preferred that you bring that information with you for the August 17th meeting.)

On page 2 of the application, questions 13, 14 and 15 about misdemeanors and felonies have been the most confusing for students. If you’re unsure how you should answer these, you may want to contact your attorney.  If you answer “yes,” you must provide documentation about the incident to the NE DHHS (read the bottom half of page 2 of the applicant letter).

You may have specific questions about other parts of this application. Those can be addressed at the meeting.

Dr. Augustine and I will be assisting your entire class in completing these applications. All application forms and attachments will be collected at the end of that presentation.

Any questions or concerns that you have prior to the meeting, please contact me or Dr. Augustine.

Thank you,

Liz

data.assign_desc:
Dr. P is researching Facebook’s effect on interpersonal and political discourse for the Wikipedia project, and he has located five articles below that all discuss research on ‘weak’ and ‘strong’ ties on Facebook.
 

http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/technology/2012/01/online_echo_chambers_a_study_of_250_million_facebook_users_reveals_the_web_isn_t_as_polarized_as_we_thought_.html (Links to an external site.)

http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2399000,00.asp (Links to an external site.)

http://allthingsd.com/20120117/facebook-is-totally-not-an-echo-chamber-says-facebook/ (Links to an external site.)

http://www.facebook.com/note.php?note_id=10150503499618859 (Links to an external site.)

 

Take a look at each of these articles (scan through each for about a minute or so). Specifically, consider the following paragraphs from the second page of the Slate article:

The other crucial thing about this study is that it is almost unthinkably enormous. At the time of the experiment, there were 500 million active users on Facebook. Bakshy’s experiment included 253 million of them and more than 75 million shared URLs, meaning that in total, the study observed nearly 1.2 billion instances in which someone was or was not presented with a certain link. This scale is unheard of in academic sociological studies, which usually involve hundreds or, at most, thousands of people communicating in ways that are far less trackable.

At the same time, there’s an obvious problem with Bakshy’s study: It could only occur with the express consent of Facebook, and in the end it produced a result that is clearly very positive for the social network. The fact that Facebook’s P.R. team contacted me about the study and allowed me to interview Bakshy suggests the company is very pleased with the result. If Bakshy’s experiment had come to the opposite conclusion—that, say, the News Feed does seem to echo our own ideas—I suspect they wouldn’t be publicizing it at all. (Bakshy told me that he has “a good amount of freedom” at the company to research whatever he wants to look into about the social network, and that no one tells him what to investigate and what to leave alone. The study is being submitted to peer-reviewed academic journals.)

Then, answer the following question: Has Dr. P adequately triangulated his sources here? Would it be possible for Dr. P to triangulate the sources from this study?

data.assign_desc:
1.  The middle ear is not a fluid filled space. It is filled with air.

2.  Vestibular and auditory information is not relayed into the CNS via the Xth cranial nerve, but rather via the VIIIth cranial nerve.

3.  Vibrations of endolymph do not stimulate hair cells in the vestibular system.  They are stimulated by movement.

4.  The cochlea is located in the temporal bone.  (TRUE)

5.  Information that enters the brain from one ear does not go to the contralateral cortex only, it goes bilaterally.

6.  The palpebra is not the circular muscle that surrounds the eye.  The palpebra is the eyelid and the orbicularis oculi is the muscle that surrounds the eye.

7.  Visual information that reaches the cortex is a reversed and inverted image of the visual fields.

8.  The fovea is not the blind spot where the optic nerve exits the eye, that is the optic disk.  The fovea is the part of the retina that is specialized for the most acute vision.

9.  The pituitary gland releases a number of hormones that control the activity of other endocrine structures.

10.  FSH and LH are hormones that affect the testes and ovaries, thyroid hormones increase energy and oxygen utilization and antidiuretic hormone affects kidney function.  Growth hormone does not affect thyroid function.
