data.assign_desc:
Your first (practice) discussion post is designed to (a) get you a first round of speaking practice while (b) introducing yourself to your classmates. Please watch this video that demonstrates how to post a video into discussions. Note that you can also upload a video into Blueline by clicking the "film" icon, click upload media, and select the appropriate video file.

Be patient as videos may not show up right away as Blueline works to embed the video. 

STEP 1: You will use use your webcam to record a 1-2 minute video telling us about yourself. [You may want to jot down some bullet-point notes to speak from.] Some things you MIGHT want to address include:

  • Where are you from? What is your town/city like?
  • What hobbies do you have?
  • What class are you looking most forward to this semester?
  • What are you most excited about related to your Critical Issues in Human Inquiry course?
  • How do you hope this course on speaking and communication will help you in the future?
  • If you have been a student in a previous online course, what tips do you have for your peers? If you have not had an online course, what concerns do you have?

NOTE: You will not be able to see your classmates videos until you post your video. 

If you have issues uploading or recording your video to the Blueline, please contact the Student DoIT desk for assistance. 

STEP 2: Step two will provide you with an opportunity to think through and apply the Five Canons of Rhetoric you read about in Chapter 1 in your replies to your classmates. 

As was introduced in the chapter, the Five Canons of Rhetoric are helpful for identifying a range of variables to consider in the construction of any speech. Whether you realized it or not, you made choices about how to construct your Student Introduction Video. Some of those choices were narrowed for you in the instructions for the video. For example, you were asked to "jot down bullet points" to speak about. This instruction is responsive to the need to organize a speech or, put another way, to consider the Canon of "Disposition."

In your replies to two classmates consider the role the canons played in the creation of your classmates' Student Introduction Video. This video demonstrates how to participate in Blueline discussions.

The following aspects of chapter 1 should be included in your replies to at least two classmates, be sure to answer each part in each reply:

  1. How did he/she use the canon of invention to help generate his/her introduction?
  2. How did the canon of disposition impact the order of his/her speech? 
  3. What choices did he/she make about style during the video?
  4. How would you characterize her/his delivery in the video?
  5. Did he/she memorize what he/she was going to say in the video? Did he/she use notes? What role did this final canon play in his/her video?

 

Below are some guidelines for your video:

When you are recording your video remember to do the following:

  • Put the camera on a stable surface.
  • Stand 1-3 feet back from the camera.
  • Adjust the camera so that it is comfortably at eye level. This will help you avoid having to look down to the camera.
  • Prepare notecards of your presentation; do not read off of your screen or a manuscript.
  • Speak in a well-lit room.
  • Speak loudly and clearly, practicing projection just as you would in front of an audience.
  • Consider the background of your video; avoid objects, posters, and people that will distract your viewers.

 

Technical Considerations:  

  • Record your video at a resolution no higher than 720p. Videos recorded in 1080p will have difficulty being uploaded.
  • Keep the length of your within the assignment expectations. Long videos of 14 minutes at high resolution have difficulty being uploaded.
  • Recording your video in an MP4 file format helps limit file size and will make uploading videos easier.
  • Some browsers work better than others. We recommend Google Chrome or Firefox. Safari can work with most features without a problem. You should avoid using Microsoft Internet Explorer.

Your third and final exam will take place at your regular lab time Apr. 27-29th.  It will be closed-book/closed-note, and you will need a pencil and non-programmable calculator.  You will have 25 minutes to complete the exam, and may leave as soon as you're done.

  • Thermodynamics of the Dissolution of Urea

and an additional 5 Qs covering general lab stuff I would expect you to know after a full year of lab work.

data.assign_desc:
-ing PROJECT

This project is designed for you to get to know your classmates and life at Creighton. You will be assigned to a group of 3-4 individuals. As a group, you will need to engage in 7 activities that require your group to spend time with each other. (Please nothing illegal or inappropriate). Your group needs to document (take pictures of) itself " ____-ing" together.

Every group needs to participate in "eating" and "Jesuit-ing." Please make "eating" a meal where you sit and dine together rather than snacking. The other 5 -ing activities are your choice. You should also come up with a group name (this does not count as an –ing activity).

Be creative in choosing your activities and remember they should be something active that end in "-ing" (and also should not be dangerous, illegal, sexual or profane in anyway). Each group member must appear in each picture, no photoshop, please!

You will then take all of your "-ing" activities and put them together in a visual presentation to show your RSP class.

  • Please submit the powerpoint or visual aid to this dropbox by the due date.
  • All group members must have equal participation in the presentation of your activities.
  • Share your group name in the presentation
  • Presentations can be fairly informal, but think about and share what this activity did for your group and interesting aspects you learned about each person during the activities.
  • You will want to spend at least 2 minutes discussing each activity.
  • Presentations should be 5-10 minutes in length.

data.assign_desc:
Analyzing a Manuscript- Independent Assignment (20 points)

Now that you have an understanding of the parts of a primary research article, and how to go about reading and analyzing one, you will be randomly assigned to perform an independent analysis of a specific article. You will follow the same steps for this manuscript as you did for the article in lab, except that you will record your answers in the electronic version of the assignment linked below. Submit your answers online using to to this assignment. 

Assignment:

  1. Read the abstract or summary
  2. Skim the paper
  3. Read the paper and try to comprehend it.
  4. Reflect and Analyze the paper, and answer the questions provided in the word file Fall2014_Manuscript Analysis Assignment.docx. Type your answers directly onto the provided word file, save and rename the flle, then upload it using the online manuscript submission feature. The name of your file should include your name and the name of the first author of the paper you analyzed using the following format: 

Last Name, First Name_author name

Please note that scientific articles are written in different styles, depending on the journal. The article you read may have no explicit introduction, the results and discussion sections may be combined, or the methods (experimental procedures) may be at the end of the article. The section headings (Introduction, Methods, Results, Discussion) listed below are meant to help you know where to look in the article for the appropriate information. You should still be able to determine the answers to the questions below, even if you paper has a slightly different format.

Creighton University at University of Alaska Anchorage

Non-Degree Seeking and Non-UAA student

This process is for you to input your information into the UAA system.  Even though you may be "registering" as a non-degree seeking student, you are a student in the OT program at Creighton University.  This is supplemental to instruction in order for you to have wireless access at UAA.  If you have prior UAA credentials, follow the procedure listed in the application and then proceed to send your information to Diana Steer as instructed below.

These steps are to get you started at UAA.  This is only to create/reactivate your UAA identity.  Creighton will register you for fall courses.

    1. Non-Degree Seeking: https://uaonline.alaska.edu/
    2. Select “Just want to take a class?”
    3. Take a Class: select ‘Non-Degree’, student, click here.
    4. Admissions Login: make appropriate selection and follow steps. Note “First time user account creation”.
    5. The video that is available provides screen shots and is a comprehensive overview for those seeking admission into UAA. Be sure to register as a non-degree seeking student.
    6. WAIT THREE DAYS and then check back into your account by logging into: https://me.uaa.alaska.edu/ (this is where you will change your login in information)
  • Note: You should receive a student ID number/username and password within in 3-4 days. When you do, utilize the following steps:
    1. Press Ctrl and click on: uaa.alaska.edu
    2. Select: “Option 1: “Change My Password”
    3. If you are having difficulties, contact:
      1. UAA Call Center
      2. (907) 786-4646 (Identify yourself as a Creighton student)
  • Email: callcenter@uaa.alaska.edu (Identify yourself as a Creighton student)
  • IMPORTANT:
    1. When you have your UAA ID number and Creighton email address:
    2. Email them to: Diana Steer, Academic Coordinator at UAA dlsteer@uaa.alaska.edu
    3. Note: UAA will push emergency notifications to your CU email account
    4. Make sure you can login at UAA using your home computer. You will need to make sure you can do this successfully prior to Creighton Welcome Week.
  • Student ID Cards:
    1. You can get your UAA ID card/Wolfcard from Student Services at:
      1. University Center: 3901 Old Seward Hwy., Anchorage, zip code 99503 or
      2. University of Alaska Anchorage Consortium Library across from Providence Hospital
  • Your ID number will only give you access to:
    1. Free public transit with your ID card
    2. Use of full wireless access at UAA
    3. Access to the anatomy lab when you register for gross anatomy spring semester
  • Fees
    1. UAA Fees for wireless services are managed through Creighton University.
    2. UAA Fees are (optional) for healthcare, library checkout and research, sporting events, and use of fitness facilities.

data.assign_desc:
Patient counseling standards originally were set in the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 (OBRA 1990), which is a law mandating that pharmacists offer counseling to patients regarding their prescriptions.  If the patient accepts this offer, pharmacists should discuss the following:

  • Name of medication
  • Intended use and expected action
  • Route, dosage form, dosage, and administration schedule
  • Proper storage
  • Common adverse effects that may be encountered
  • Techniques for self-monitoring of drug therapy
  • Prescription refill information
  • Action to take if a dose is missed
  • Potential drug–drug or drug–food interactions or other therapeutic contraindications

Although the law was intended for Medicaid patients, individual states adopted rules to make counseling applicable to other patients, as well. Thus, counseling is one of the tools that may be used to provide MTM services. One of the limitations of counseling, however, is that information generally is provided in a one-way, provider-centered manner (i.e., pharmacist to patient or pharmacist to caregiver). Instead, the pharmacist should ask questions to elicit needed information from the patient to fill the medication(s) in question and also to ensure that all of the patient's medications are providing optimal benefit.

Before your counseling session, please review Patient Counseling information under the Resources Module.  This includes the Patient Counseling Checklist, the Patient Counseling Videos, and the Patient Counseling PowerPoint in the BlueCast so you know what to expect.

 

List of Medications:

Medication           Electronic Prescription
Carisoprodol Carisoprodol Prescription
Ibuprofen Ibuprofen Prescription
Oxycodone Oxycodone Prescription
Sumatriptan Sumatriptan Prescription

data.assign_desc:
Use Frankl's method (which we used in class) in order to discern the right course of action in the following situation/scenario. Write a short (50 word or so) answer to each question below in your response.

 

 

 

  1. What are the social forces (people, groups of people, the way we think about how people think in our own heads) that make this decision difficult?

 

 

 

  1. What implicit or overt arguments are those social forces making (overtly or implicitly/in the head of the person in the situation) as you might encounter the situation below?

 

 

 

  1. What would Frankl argue is the right thing to do here? More importantly, why do you think Frankl would argue that the person in this situation should take a particular course of action?

 

 

It’s the first Friday night of the semester, and you decide to go out to a party with your new friends. Everyone seems to be drinking a lot more than you expected and you’re a little nervous. You decide to go to the party anyway and hope that the walk there will help you and your friends sober up a bit. Unfortunately, this is not the case, and once you’re there, your friends only drink more. You’re uncomfortable, but you don’t know anyone here very well, and you don’t want to walk home alone. Then, you see one of your friends throwing up near the porch, and he/she doesn’t seem to be stopping any time soon. At this point, you’re worried, but you don’t want to get anyone into trouble. What should you do?
data.assign_title: Long Response #3: Party Night with Your Friends

Review the notes for the lectures given on Sept 19, 22 and 24 (topics include history of life and fossil record; and the bacteria/archaea).  Protists are NOT on this quiz.  Also review the accompanying material in Chap 28-29, especially if anything in the lecture notes seems unclear to you.

You will be allowed two attempts and your grade will represent the latest of the attempts.  

Keep in mind the academic honesty policy and complete this quiz independently without assistance from another person.  You must be logged in under your own student ID in order to have the points go in the grade book accurately. 

Good luck!

data.assign_desc:
This information is for entry-level students.  POTD students need to view the specific course waiver information in their respective pathway module.

Course Waiver Policy – Please click on the following link BEFORE completing the form to review the course waiver policy . This policy will explain the purpose of the waivers and the waiver procedure. This is the ONLY opportunity you have to waive future coursework during your entire academic career at Creighton University.

Deadlines for Course Waiver Applications and Supporting Documentation

Medical Science Foundation Courses for ALL semesters
Deadline: July 15, 2016

Course Examples (not inclusive of all options): BMS 404, Physiology; OTD 339, Clinical Anatomy; PTD 310 (Physical Therapy), Human Anatomy; BMS 301, Biochemistry; MIC 541, Microbiology and Immunology.

Exceptions will only be considered for students who receive admission letters after this date. This means no one can apply for a medical science course waiver after the July 15, 2016 deadline or, in the case of an exception, after classes begin in the first semester of the first professional year.

Discipline-Oriented Courses

Courses offered in the first semester of the professional program
Deadline: Friday, August 19, 2016

Courses offered in all other semesters of the professional program
Deadline: Friday, December 16, 2016
Course Examples: PHA 350, Intro to Research Methods/Biostatistics; OTD 300 Research Proposal I; PHA 321, Health Systems and Patient Safety

The curricula and all required coursework for the Occupational Therapy, Pharmacy and Physical Therapy programs can be found in the School of Pharmacy and Health Professions School Catalog.

Application

To complete a course waiver, you must visit the Course Waiver Application. Only electronic applications are accepted. Courses submitted for consideration for waiver must have been completed within the last five years with a grade of “C” or above. A separate application must be completed for each course.

Required Supporting Documentation

All of the following must be submitted:

  • Course bulletin description from previous university/college
  • Unofficial transcript
  • Course syllabus, from the term in which the course was completed, including topic schedule or separate topic schedule – If you are unable to locate your syllabus, check with a classmate or contact the course instructor. The instructor may have a syllabus for the term in which you completed the course.
  • View full checklist in the course waiver application

Decision Options

The following options may take place when you have fully completed a course waiver:

  • The course is evaluated as fully equivalent and the waiver approved
  • The course has considerable deficiencies and the waiver is denied, and/or
  • The course may have a minor deficiency in which case the student is given the opportunity to take a challenge exam

The challenge exams are administered during Welcome Week (see schedule for challenge exam times and location). If you pass an exam, the waiver is granted. Once you submit a waiver, you are not obligated to take the challenge exam if it is offered. If you are offered a challenge exam but you do not sit for it, you must complete the course.

Supporting Documentation Mailing Address:
Amy Wilson, Pharm.D.
Assistant Dean for Academic Affairs
School of Pharmacy and Health Professions
Creighton University
2500 California Plz
Omaha, NE 68178
(402) 280-1147

This is the ONLY opportunity you have to waive future coursework during your entire academic career at Creighton University.

Once you have read this information, click "Take Quiz" at the bottom of this page.

data.assign_desc:
Before lab, you should...

  • Read the lab manual (including all parts of the Introduction and Procedure).
    • Mark it up with any notes or questions you may have!
  • Recognize that we're using dye AND bleach - dress accordingly!
  • Write an introduction for this experiment in your lab notebook.  This intro is often a bit longer than others.
    • Make sure that the intro addresses not only how you are going to collect data, but how you are going to determine what order the reaction is.
    • Don't forget to include relevant mathematical and chemical equations.
  • Make sure you
    • understand how the the integrated rate laws "map" to a line.  (e.g. Do you understand why I say that k' is the negative slope of a plot of concentration versus time when dealing with a zero-order reaction (eqn. 6b and the text below it.))
  • Refer to Sections 12.1-12.5 and 12.7 of your textbook, or go to Dr. Gunn's office hours if you need more help with the background information.

By the end of lab, you should...

  • Be able to use visible spectroscopy and graphical analysis to determine the order of one of the reactants in a chemical reaction
  • Be able to perform a kinetics experiment in real time.
  • Be able to determine the observed rate constant for a reaction and half-life of a reactant from experimental data.

data.assign_desc:
In addition to the academic requirements for admission, candidates must possess skills and abilities that will allow them to successfully complete the curriculum and practice the profession of pharmacy. Creighton University Medical Center School of Pharmacy and Health Professions has an ethical responsibility for the safety of patients for whom the students come into contact. Therefore, patient safety is a major factor in establishing requirements for physical, cognitive, and emotional capabilities of applicants for communicational, motor, intellectual-conceptual (integrative and qualitative), behavioral, and social skills and abilities. The School is committed to enabling students with disabilities by reasonable means of accommodations to complete the course of study leading to the Doctor of Pharmacy degree. Some accommodations cannot be made because they are not reasonable. For example, the use of a trained intermediary is not acceptable. The use of a trained intermediary is however, not acceptable in many clinical situations in that it implies that a candidate’s judgment must be mediated by someone else’s power of selection and observation.

Observational.  The candidate must be able to visually observe and interpret presented information. This will necessitate the functional use of vision, hearing, and somatic senses.

Communicational. The candidate must be able to communicate effectively with patients, caregivers, faculty/staff, and all members of the health care team. These skills include the appropriate use of spoken and written English, hearing, and reading.

Motor. The candidate must have sufficient motor function and skills necessary to perform basic tasks in the training and practice of pharmacy. Examples of such tasks may include the compounding of medicinals, administration of drugs of the provision of basic cardiac life support. Such actions require the coordination of both gross and fine muscular movements, equilibrium, and functional use of the senses.

Intellectual, Conceptual, Integrative and Quantitative Abilities. Problem solving and critical thinking are key skills to proper performance of the responsibilities of a pharmacist. The candidate must be able to measure, calculate, reason, analyze, synthesize, and integrate information that is essential to fully develop these skills.

Behavioral and Social Attributes. Students must be of sufficient emotional and mental health to utilize fully his or her intellectual ability, to exercise good judgment and ethical standards, to complete patient care responsibilities promptly, and to relate to others with courtesy, compassion, maturity, and respect for their dignity. The ability to participate collaboratively as a professional team member is essential. The pharmacy student must display emotional health in spite of a stressful work, changing environments, and clinical uncertainties. The pharmacy student must be able to modify behavior in response to constructive criticism. He/she must exhibit behavior and intellectual functioning which does not differ from acceptable standards.

Attainment of Technical Standards.  Inability to comply with these technical standards may result in course failure. Applicants are encouraged to voluntarily discuss their disabilities with the Director of Admission and the Assistant / Associate Dean for Academic Affairs of the School in order to consider and prepare for the accommodations that may be needed. After enrollment, a student with a disability who wishes to request reasonable accommodations may directly contact the Assistant / Associate Dean for Academic Affairs of the School or the Creighton University Office of Services for Students with Disabilities. Verification and documentation of the disability by a qualified professional, such as a physician or psychologist, will be needed before reasonable accommodations are made. Accommodations will not be considered reasonable if they affect the substance of the Doctor of Pharmacy educational program, compromise the School’s educational standards, and/or negatively affect the safety of students and/or other people, including patients, with whom they may come into contact in the course of their studies. If accommodations are provided, this information will be kept in strict confidence.

Students must evaluate themselves for compliance with these technical standards. A handwritten signature is required prior to starting the pharmacy curriculum and once yearly while the student is in good standing in the program.  If the student’s ability to comply with these standards changes unexpectedly at any time during his/her enrollment in the pharmacy program, he/she has the obligation to inform the Assistant/Associate Dean for Academic Affairs immediately for a determination of the need to seek temporary or long term accommodations.

Signing (electronically) this document will serve as testimony that the student is in compliance with these standards and understands the responsibilities it outlines.  A student who is dismissed from the program and subsequently reinstated must re-sign this document as testimony that the student is in compliance with these standards. 

View PDF version

Once you have read this information, click "Take Quiz" at the bottom of this page.

data.assign_desc:
Bryan, a freshman, is in an intermediate-level psychology class that is required for his major in education. Before spring break, his professor, Dr. Lockon, provides the following assignment instructions to the students. The assignment is worth 20% of the students’ grade:

 

Locate two academic articles from a well-respected psychology journal on the same topic. In a 7-page paper, summarize the information in the articles, comparing and contrasting their outcomes. Then, provide a personal response to the articles giving your opinion on the topic.

 

Dr. Lockon has provided no examples of good writing to the students aside from the course textbook. S/he gave unclear responses to students’ questions in class about the assignment. Additionally, Dr. Lockon has not outlined the characteristics of a well-respected psychology journal (So far, Bryan has browsed a few articles from Psychology Today online).

 

Some students have expressed frustration outside of class about Dr. Lockon’s assignments and instructions. Further, before the start of the semester, Bryan had read online reviews of Dr. Lockon that complained that her/his assignments are vague and her/his grading is harsh. Bryan resolves to visit Dr. Lockon during office hours on the Thursday before break in order to gain some clarification regarding the assignment.



Script

 

<Knock, knock, knock>

 

Dr. L: Come in.

 

Bryan: Hey, Dr. Lockon. I’m wondering if I can ask you some questions about the assignment for break

 

Dr. L: Sure, we went over this in class, but go ahead.

 

Bryan: I’m not really sure what you’re asking us to do. I know we need to write five pages on a topic, and I know we need to summarize some articles, but I’m not sure where to start.

 

Dr. L: Have you chosen a topic yet?

 

Bryan: Yeah – I’m thinking of writing on poverty and its effects on emotional development at the middle school level.

 

Dr. L: Great! Sounds like you’re on the right track.

 

Bryan: Yeah, but I’m still not sure where to start my paper.

 

Dr. L: Your topic sounds good.

 

Bryan: But I’m not sure where to start looking for research…

 

Dr. L: Where do you start the search for the answer to any question?

 

Bryan: Google.

 

Dr. L: I would say the library. Have you gone to the library yet?

 

Bryan: No, I’ve just browsed some articles online.

 

Dr. L: On the library’s website?

 

Bryan: No, through Google.

 

Dr. L: Well, I can’t help you if you don’t go to the right sources to seek out information.

 

Bryan: Well, you didn’t really tell us where to look exactly… I’m just confused… I think a lot of people in the class are confused about this assignment. No one seems to know what’s going on.

 

Dr. L: Ha! No one? So you’ve polled the class.

 

Bryan: Well, I think the students are just confused about what your assignment is. They don’t think you explained it very well. Everyone says your explanation wasn’t very helpful.

 

Dr. L: Bryan, I can’t help those who haven’t helped themselves. You haven’t even been to the library yet. Go visit the library, and then we can talk again.

 

Bryan: Ok...

 

Dr. L: Is there anything else you need?

 

Bryan: No, that was my question.

 

Dr. L: I need to get to a meeting, so stop by or email me if you have any more questions.

 

<¡Fin!>


How should Bryan proceed?

data.assign_desc:
1.  B. Somatic neuron cell bodies are not located in muscle tissue.  They are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord.

2.  A. Some axons in the CNS and PNS are myelinated (true).

3. C.  Synapses are places where release of chemical neurotransmitters by presynaptic cells afftects electrical activity of postsynaptic cells.  (all other options were false).

4.  A.  Most, or all, of drug effects in the CNS occur by modyifying synaptic transmission. (true)

5.  D. Severing a peripheral nerve does not result in permanent loss of nerve function.  Peripheral nerves regenerate.

6.  D  The spinal cord is not the same length as the vertebral coumn.  It ends at around L1-L2 vertebral level.

7.  A.  A dermatome is the area of skin innervated by a spinal nerve. (true)

8.  B. Epidural anesthetics are injected superficial to the dura mater.  (epi means upon/outside)

9.  A. Somatic motor neuron cell bodies are located in the gray matter of the anterior horn of the spinal cord. (true)

10.  A.  Sensory nformation does not enter the ventral horn of the spinal cord, it enters the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.  All other options were true.

data.assign_desc:
Before lab, you should...

  • Read the lab manual (including all parts of the Introduction and Procedure).
    • Mark it up with any notes or questions you may have!
  • Write an introduction for this experiment in your lab notebook.
  • Draft the procedure for determining ΔH.
    • YOU get to decide the volume of water to use, the mass of urea, the settings, etc.
    • You need to decide what equations you use and what data you need to calculate this.
    • Refer to the Enthalpy of Neutralization and Hess' Law procedures from CHM 204 for guidance (also found in your 204 lab manual).
    • If you draft this ahead of time, you won't have to rewrite it - just cross out changes (if any) and note the change.
  • Think about how you will calculate Keq from the data you collect.
  • Refer to Sections 16.7-16.8 and 16.11 of your textbook, or go to Dr. Gunn's office hours if you need more help with the background information.

By the end of lab, you should...

  • Be able to determine the equilibrium constant for the dissolution of a substance
  • Be able to devise and carry out a procedure for the determination of ΔH for a reaction
  • Use appropriate equations and experimental data to determine ΔG and ΔS for the dissolution of a substance.

data.assign_desc:
Your first exam will take place at the beginning of your lab period the week of Feb 16 - Feb 18.  It will be closed-book/closed-note, and you will need a pencil and non-programmable calculator.

This exam will cover the following experiments:

  • Evaporation and Intermolecular Attractions
  • Spectroscopy and Beer's Law
  • Kinetics
  • Equilibrium

and have a couple of questions about the Molar Mass of a Monoprotic Acid experiment (the same type as might appear on a regular quiz, to make sure you have prepared for it).

Questions will focus on your understanding of the experiments, but are not intended to test memorization of experimental details.  For example, I won't expect you to be able to list the five compounds we studied in the "Evaporation and Intermolecular Attractions" experiment, but if I gave you two data sets and two compounds, I might expect you to be able to match which compound would correspond with which data set, based on your ability to predict relative strengths of intermolecular forces and your understanding of how that would affect the change in temperature during evaporation.

To prepare, I suggest you

  • review the experiments we've done, make sure you understand what we did and why, and can analyze similar data
  • review previous quizzes - as well as the "possible" questions that didn't make it on to a quiz.  At a minimum, that will help you understand how I ask questions and what I have previously identified as being important.
  • review the experiment links above, re-reading the "By the end of lab, you should..." to remind yourself of the skills identified as important.
